Narrative: An unidentified person fatally shot another man, 27, in the school parking lot. Police did not immediately identify the person and did not make any arrests.

A sixteen-year-old opened fire on his classmates, hitting and injuring another 16-year-old student. A teacher in the classroom persuaded the shooter to put down the firearm and surrender to police. Police believe the gun belonged to his brother.

A 21 year-old used a semi-automatic pistol he had purchased earlier in the day to shoot and kill his former girlfriend, 20, her uncle, 53, and her 12-year-old cousin in the school parking lot. The man turned himself in to police later that afternoon.

A 34-year-old shot and injured a man, 45, in his office with a 9mm handgun. The shooter then shot himself in the stomach when fleeing the scene, which was believed to have been unintentional. The shooting followed an argument that had occurred between the two the day before. According to police, the handgun used in the shooting had been stolen during a burglary.

A twenty-nine-year-old and a 32-year-old shot and killed a 17-year-old student outside of the basketball gym. It started with a brawl inside of the gym after the basketball game between players of both teams. Law enforcement apprehended one of the shooters near the school and charged him with first-degree murder.

A twenty-two-year-old shot and injured three people. The shooter had had an argument with two of the victims prior to the shooting. Law enforcement arrested the shooter and charged him with aggravated assault with a deadly weapon.

A felony theft suspect, 22, was pursued by police into the parking lot of a community college. After fighting with an officer and grabbing the officer’s stun gun, the suspect was shot multiple times. He died at the scene.

An unidentified 15-year-old shot and wounded an eighth grade student in the school courtyard. A school safety officer then disarmed the 15-year-old. Atlanta Police said that the shooting was not random and that there had had been an argument prior to the shooting.

A man shot and injured another man in the arm; according to the shooter, the victim had taken aggressive steps toward him. On February 24, 2014, the shooter was convicted of aggravated assault with a deadly weapon and possession of a weapon on school property among other charges.

School name: Martin Luther King Jr Senior High School
Narrative: An assistant girls basketball coach at Martin Luther King Jr. High School, 70. was walking two female students to their vehicles in the school paring lot when two armed teens ambushed them. The coach opened fire and fatally wounded a teen, 16, and shot and injured the other teen. Police took the coach into custody.

Police were pursuing an armed person into a parking lot on the campus of Indian River State College. A bystander in the parking lot was injured when shots were fired. It is unclear who fired the shot that injured her.
A twenty-year-old fatally shot an 18-year-old on the school's basketball court. This occurred after the victim did not pay the shooter $5 he had lost on a bet.

A seventeen-year-old unintentionally shot herself in the thigh with a handgun in the courtyard of the high school. Law enforcement charged her with possession of a pistol by a minor and carrying a weapon within a school safety zone.
A school resource officer unintentionally discharged his service weapon inside Highland High School. No one was injured.

Police responded to the Manchester Community College after reports of a gun on campus. While searching the campus, an officer's gun unintentionally discharged, injuring his foot. No one else was injured, and police did not locate anyone with a gun on campus.
A thirty-year-old threatened to shoot his roommate in the residence they shared on campus. He held his roommate at gunpoint but eventually released him before fatally shooting himself.

Intent: Self-harm - no intent to hurt others
Narrative: A thirteen-year-old fatally shot himself in the school bathroom with a firearm he had brought from his home.
An eighteen-year-old shot and injured two women in a classroom that was part of a satellite campus. He was charged with two counts of attempted murder.

An unidentified person shot and injured someone, 23, outside of a residence hall on campus. Police believed that the shooting was in retaliation for a fight that had occurred on campus earlier in the day. Law enforcement did not apprehend the person.
A person unidentified by the press fired a gun on campus, injuring three students. Press reports and media did not provide further information regarding the identity of the person.

Intent: Self-harm - no intent to hurt others
Narrative: A sophomore at Temple High School shot himself in the head on the school's tennis courts. He was taken to a hospital in critical condition but died of his injuries. No other students were injured, and the school was locked down in response.
A twenty-two year-old shot and injured an unidentified student in a residence hall after an argument. He was charged with attempted murder.

Three days after the Boston Marathon bombing, an officer at MIT, 27, was shot multiple times in his car on campus by one of the brothers involved — twice in the side of the head and once between the eyes. The victim died as a result of his injuries.

Intent: Self-harm - no intent to hurt others
Narrative: A seventeen-year-old tried to take his own life using a handgun in a classroom. Law enforcement reported that approximately 22 students witnessed the shooting. He was transported to a medical facility and survived.

Tularosa police engaged in a gunfight on the school campus with a man, 19, after an officer recognized the man and confronted him, believing there was a warrant out for his arrest. The man had pulled out a rifle, causing the officer and sheriff’s deputies to open fire. The shooter was hit several times and died at the scene.

While sitting in his car in a campus parking lot, a student, 22, unintentionally fired his handgun, hitting himself in the thigh. He was treated at a local hospital for non-life threatening injuries. Campus security announced that, as a concealed carry permit holder, he was entitled to carry a gun on campus and would not be charged.

During an altercation between several female students on campus, a mother to one of the girls pointed a gun at a group of people and then fired it into the ground. She was later arrested and charged with reckless endangerment and certain person forbidden to possess firearms.

A student brought a gun to school in his book bag which discharged, according to witnesses, when the bag was dropped. A student, 12, was hit in the leg. He was airlifted to Miami Children's Hospital with non-life threatening injuries, and the school was placed on temporary lockdown.

A 23-year-old fatally shot his father, 55, and brother, 25, at their home, and set the building on fire. He then shot and injured a passing motorist, carjacked another motorist, and ordered her to drive to campus. While in the car, he shot at a bus and into a neighborhood. On campus, he shot a man, his daughter, 26, and a woman, 68, before responding police fatally shot him.

A shootout occurred at Hidden Valley Elementary School between two individuals and an undercover officer. The individuals, both 17, sold drugs to an informant and undercover police officer in the parking lot of the school. As the informant and officer walked away, the teenagers opened fire and hit the informant in the shoulder. The officer returned fire and shot one of the individuals, who later died at the hospital from a head injury.

School name: Alexander W. Dreyfoos School of the Arts
Narrative: A fifty-three-year-old school custodian fatally shot two other school custodians inside the school's maintenance room. After the shooting the shooter fled to an unidentifed location outside of the U.S., according to press; he was sentenced to life in prison in 2017.

An unknown person(s) fatally shot a man, 38, in the school parking lot. In 2015, law enforcement arrested two men in connection with the shooting; however, their role in the incident is not clear. A third man was also arrested, but it is still unclear if all 3 were involved and if so, who was the shooter.

School name: Ronald E McNair Discover Learning Academy Elementary School
Narrative: A twenty-year-old fired an AK-47 while inside an elementary school, but did not physically injure anyone. The school bookkeeper convinced the shooter to surrender and was successful in detaining him until law enforcement arrived. He was arrested and was ultimately sentenced to 20 years in prison.

A five-year-old student brought a gun to school in his backpack. The firearm discharged in the school cafeteria but no one was injured. The child's parents were charged with reckless endangerment, a felony.
A man, 52, unintentionally fired his service weapon in the police headquarters at Southwestern College. No one was injured.

A fifteen-year-old was shot and killed when gunfire erupted during a dispute on campus after a football game. Two others were wounded. Three people were arrested and charged with murder. The charges were brought to a grand jury, which did not issue any murder charges but indicted four people for possessing a handgun and displaying it in a threatening manner on school property. One of the four was also charged with aggravated assault for shooting at an occupied vehicle.
A school resource officer at York Comprehensive High School had his service weapon holstered when it unintentionally discharged on the grounds of the school.

An eighteen-year-old fired a handgun during a school fire drill, injuring a 15-year-old. The shooter claimed that he had been bullied for months and brought a gun to school protect himself. He pled guilty to assault with a deadly weapon and discharging a firearm on school property, among other charges.
An unknown person fatally shot a man, 20, on campus. Law enforcement did not make any arrests.

Intent: Self-harm - no intent to hurt others
Narrative: A nineteen-year-old fatally shot himself in the school parking lot while several athletic events were taking place.

An unidentified 16-year-old student was shot in the leg while getting ready for practice. Another unidentified 17-year-old was hit by a stray bullet. The shooting is believed to have occurred due to a previous altercation.

Intent: Self-harm - no intent to hurt others
Narrative: A sixteen-year-old fatally shot himself with a handgun in the courtyard during the school lunch hour.
A twelve-year-old fatally shot his math teacher and shot and injured two other students before fatally shooting himself on a school basketball court. He used a gun that belonged to his parents.

While police were on campus for a safety demonstration, a child unintentionally fired an officer's rifle that was mounted on a police motorbike. Three students sustained shrapnel injuries, though nobody was shot.

Intent: Self-harm - no intent to hurt others
Narrative: A twenty-three-year-old fatally shot himself on campus. He was formerly a student at the school.
At least one unknown person fired a handgun, injuring someone, 21, on campus. Police did not identify or arrest anyone.

An unknown assailant shot and injured a 17-year-old high school football player on campus during a confrontation between a group of students who did not attend the school and members of the school's football team. Law enforcement stated that the victim was a bystander to the confrontation.

School name: South Dakota School of Mines and Technology
Intent: Self-harm - no intent to hurt others
Narrative: A thirty-seven-year-old assistant professor fatally shot himself in the electrical engineering building.

A seventeen-year-old shot and injured a15-year-old on campus during the afternoon dismissal. The two were involved in an argument when the shooter took out a handgun and shot the victim in the face and stomach. In 2014, the shooter was convicted of attempted murder and sentenced to 25 years in prison.
An eighteen-year-old shot and killed a 17-year-old student in the gymnasium. The shooter then fatally shot himself.
Four students, one armed with a handgun, shot and injured a teacher at the school during an attempted robbery of a school laptop.

A 16-year old student, not identified by the press, shot and injured an unidentified 17-year-old student in the thigh in front of the school building as classes were being dismissed. The 16-year-old was charged with aggravated assault, carrying a weapon on school property, and altering the serial numbers on the handgun.

A twelve-year-old shot and injured two students in the school gym. A security officer received minor injuries when helping a teacher to disarm the shooter. The firearm the shooter used belonged to his parents. He was sentenced to ten years in state custody.
Two unidentified males fired shots on the playground, leading school administrators to place the school on lockdown. Law enforcement did not make any arrests.

A seventeen-year-old bought a gun from a 19-year-old in the school gym. Several minutes after completing the purchase, the gun discharged, hitting and injuring a student, 17, and an 18-year-old female, not identified by the press. The shooter was charged with aggravated assault and weapons possession is currently serving a two-year term in a juvenile facility. Investigators reported that they believed the shooting to be unintentional.
An unidentified person shot someone, 19, after a basketball game. Law enforcement did not apprehend the person.

A twenty-three-year-old shot someone, 21, in an academic building. The shooter was arrested immediately after leaving the building following the shooting. The shooter pled guilty to murder and was sentenced to 65 years in prison.
A nineteen-year-old fatally shot a 20-year-old outside a campus dormitory during an argument. He was charged with first-degree murder.

A group of students became involved in a lunchtime argument in the school parking lot, during which one of the students, 18, pulled out a handgun and shot someone in the stomach. The victim, who was the father of one of the students at the school, sustained serious injuries. The shooter was later arrested and sentenced to 25 years in prison for aggravated battery with a firearm.
Police found an unidentified 20-year-old man shot and injured on campus next to a residence hall after an intramural basketball game. Law enforcement did not apprehend anyone.

A 17-year old male showed up to school to register, despite not being a current student. When three police officers arrived to pick him up after reports he’d become disorderly, the teen started throwing punches and slashing an officer with a kitchen knife. One officer fired two shots, hitting the teen in the arm. He was taken to the hospital in a serious condition. Police announced he would be charged with three counts of attempted murder.
An unknown assailant fired a gun on campus injuring an unidentified man in the shoulder. Law enforcement did not apprehend the assailant. The victim's identity was not released to the press.

School name: Eastern Florida State College - Palm Bay
Narrative: Three men engaged in a fight on campus. During the fight, a man, 24, used a gun to shoot one of the other men in the chest. All three men later claimed they were acting in self-defense. Police charged them with disorderly conduct and one of the men, additionally, with aggravated battery. No charges were brought against the shooter for firing the weapon.

A twenty-year-old, a 23-year-old, a 20-year-old, and a 17-year-old were arrested for misconduct involving weapons after a shooting incident on campus. According to police, the four fired shots into the air on campus during a high school basketball game. It was not determined if they were charged with assault.
An unknown assailant shot and injured a 15-year-old girl in the parking lot of the school. Law enforcement did not make any arrests.

Intent: Self-harm - no intent to hurt others
Narrative: A seventeen-year-old fatally shot himself in a classroom with his own hunting rifle.

A sixteen-year-old, was trying to break up a fight when he was shot and injured by a seventeen-year-old. The shooter was charged, among other things, with assault with a deadly weapon and discharging a weapon on school property.

A 21-year-old fatally shot his fiancée while they were sitting in his vehicle in a parking lot on campus. Law enforcement determined that the man had stolen the gun from a friend, and charged him with first-degree murder.
Two 17-year-old boys were arrested for firing shots at each other in the school's parking lot outside of a basketball game. No one was injured.

A forty-two-year-old man fatally shot a 30-year-old man when the victim was in his car in the parking lot outside of the school. The shooter was angry that the victim was dating his ex-wife. Law enforcement arrested the shooter at the school and charged him with first-degree murder. He was later found guilty of second-degree murder and armed criminal action in 2015.

Campus police responded to a late-night noise complaint in a dormitory complex. As people fled the scene, a man entered a vehicle and tried to strike an officer, who opened fire in response. The man was taken to a nearby hospital and treated for non-life threatening injuries.
An unknown person fired gunshots at several college students in a residence hall during an altercation. No one was injured. Law enforcement did not make any arrests.
A seventeen-year-old teen got into a fight after a school dance on campus and shot and injured a 16-year-old male. He was charged with attempted second-degree murder.

During an altercation at a university dance on campus, an unknown person who was allegedly part of the altercation fired a gunshot into the air and fled. There were no reported injuries and the police did not apprehend the person.

A twenty-two-year-old man attended a party where he got into an argument. He went to his car that was parked in a university parking lot and recklessly fired a gun several times into the air. Law enforcement charged him with carrying a concealed deadly weapon, reckless endangerment, terroristic threatening and possession of a firearm while under the influence of alcohol.

An argument between students in the school parking lot escalated until shots were fired into the air. Both the high school and a nearby elementary school were placed on lockdown in response. Police arrested multiple people in relation to the incident.

Police responded to a report of an on-campus attempted robbery after a single shot was heard in the University Village located on campus. No injuries were reported and no arrests were made. Police confirmed shots were fired but did not make any arrests.

A twenty-four-year-old man shot himself in the hand during an argument with two women on campus. He then fled to a residence hall to ask a friend for help in hiding the weapon before law enforcement took him to the hospital and charged him with carrying a concealed weapon.

Two 17-year-old juniors from another high school drove past campus in an SUV, and one of them fired a handgun at the school, which was in session. Officials placed the school on lockdown as a precaution. The two teens were later arrested and charged with multiple offenses.

A group of unknown individuals fired shots from a vehicle into a crowd of approximately 100 students attending a school event on campus. The shots killed a 19-year-old. Law enforcement did not make any arrests.

Intent: Self-harm - no intent to hurt others
Narrative: A 14-year-old student, trying to take his own life with a gun on school grounds, injured himself in the face but survived. Law enforcement indicated that he did not intend to harm anyone else.
A fifty-five-year-old man fatally shot his estranged wife, 42, in the parking lot of a school.

Two unknown assailants shot a 19-year-old man in the parking lot on campus. One pulled out a handgun and demanded his wallet. When the victim tried to grab the weapon, a member of the group shot him in the arm. No one was apprehended.

A 19-year-old man approached a student near a parking garage on campus and threatened the student with a gun. During a brief struggle, the man shot the student in the hand. Police apprehended him and said he has an "extensive criminal record." They also apprehended a second man, 20, who was involved in related robberies.

An unknown person shot and injured an unidentified teenager during a verbal argument between two groups of students at the school basketball court. Law enforcement does not have any suspects and has not apprehended anyone.

An unknown person shot into a residence hall and an unidentified individual was injured by debris from the gunshot. Two students heard multiple gunshots and alerted law enforcement. Law enforcement did not make any arrests and do not have any suspects.

A twenty-year-old man shot and injured another person, 21, on campus during an altercation. Law enforcement arrested the shooter and charged him with aggravated assault, possession of a firearm during the commission of a crime, and possession of a firearm on school grounds.

A twenty-four-year-old unintentionally shot and injured an unidentified student in the school parking lot. The shooter and the student had been returning from a party when the shooter began playing with a semi-automatic pistol. The gun discharged and a bullet bounced off the ground and struck the student in the leg. Law enforcement charged the shooter with first-degree wanton endangerment.

Intent: Self-harm - no intent to hurt others
Narrative: An individual shot himself on the roof of the campus parking deck. Law enforcement did not determine his identity or provide further updates of his condition.

An eighteen-year-old fatally shot a 10-year-old girl, who had been playing with her sister and friends on the school playground. According to police, the girl was caught in the crossfire when the shooter exchanged gunfire with someone else, who was seated on the steps of the playground. The shooter was charged with homicide.
A twenty-six-year-old man fatally shot a 19-year-old, and shot and injured two other students inside a campus building. He was charged with first-degree murder among other charges.
A fifteen-year-old teen fatally shot a 14-year-old student and shot and injured a teacher, 50, before fatally shooting himself. The shootings occurred in the gym locker room at the school.

After playing basketball at the school, four boys climbed into a truck in the school parking lot. One of the boys picked up a loaded gun that was in the truck. As he was handing it to one of the other boys, 15, it unintentionally discharged, hitting the boy in the head. The boy later died at Saint Francis Medical Center.

A thirty-five-year-old woman attempted to shoot her ex-husband in his office on campus. During an altercation at his office, they struggled for the gun and the weapon discharged without resulting in any injuries. Law enforcement arrested the shooter and charged her with attempted murder, aggravated battery, and discharging a firearm on school property.

A twenty-one-year-old and a 16-tear-old were arrested for shooting at each other. They were both charged with first-degree assault and possession of a handgun on school grounds. Neither person attended the school.

A seventeen-year-old fatally shot two teens and wounded another in the parking lot of an elementary school. Law enforcement charged the shooter with two counts of second-degree murder, one count of use of a firearm in the commission of a felony, and one count of possession of a firearm by a convicted felon.
A professor was teaching a class when a gun in his pocket unintentionally discharged, injuring him in the foot. None of the 20 students in the class at the time were injured.
An eighteen-year-old shot and injured another student, 17, during an argument on campus. The shooter was charged with aggravated assault.

A group of teenagers got into a fight in the academy parking lot, and at some point one of them fired a gun, hitting another person, who was taken to a hospital to be treated for non-life threatening images. Police arrested five teenagers for questioning and recovered two guns that may have been involved in the incident.

Intent: Self-harm - no intent to hurt others
Narrative: A fourteen-year-old fatally shot himself in a school bathroom with his father's .40-caliber Smith and Wesson pistol. The teen's father later told investigators that he unintentionally left the key to the gun box at home, which allowed his son access to the firearm.

Before the start of classes, a 39-year-old teacher was in the restroom when her gun was fired unintentionally. Bullet hit the toilet, and the fragments from both the bullet and the toilet injured the teacher. No students witnessed the shooting. She was charged with one count of discharging a firearm and subsequently resigned from the school.
During an argument, a 21-year-old shot and injured another student, 20, at a residence hall on the school's campus. The shooter pled guilty to battery by means of a deadly weapon.
An unknown assailant shot and injured three individuals outside of on-campus residence halls. Law enforcement did not apprehend anyone.
A fifteen-year-old shot and injured another student, 16 on the campus of the school. The shooter was charged with assault with a deadly weapon with intent to kill.

A sixteen-year-old shot and injured a 15-year-old in the school hallway while the victim was leaving class. Law enforcement charged the shooter with attempted murder and unlawful possession of a weapon on school property.

A eighteen-year-old fatally shot a 17 year-old in the school parking lot after a basketball game. The shooter attended a different high school, but was at the game visiting with friends. After the shooting, the shooter turned himself into the police and was charged with first-degree murder.

A twenty-four-year-old fired shots outside of a classroom on campus. No one was injured. The shooter stated that the gunshot was a "warning shot" and that he did not aim the gun at any students. Law enforcement arrested the shooter and charged him with discharging a gun on school property.
An unknown person fired two gunshots in a campus dormitory. There were no reported injuries. Law enforcement did not apprehend the person.
An unknown person shot and injured a 22-year-old during a physical altercation in a parking lot on campus. Law enforcement did not apprehend the person.
An unidentified thirteen-year old student brought a loaded gun to school in his backpack. As he was showing the gun to his friends, he dropped it and the firearm discharged, injuring him in the leg.

A fifteen-year-old entered the school cafeteria during lunch with a loaded gun. He then shot his two cousins as well as three other classmates. One student died at the scene. One cousin and two of the classmates died from their injuries days later. After shooting his classmates, the shooter then shot and killed himself. The gun he used belonged to his father, who owned it illegally.

A 31-year-old shot and wounded three people in the school library: two students and a library employee. When law enforcement arrived, they ordered the shooter to drop his weapon. When he refused, officers fatally shot the shooter.

A man, 35, was being escorted off campus by safety officers because of “peculiar behavior.” He engaged in a struggle with two officers and pulled out a handgun — which prompted one of the officers to fatally shoot him. One of the officers was treated for a minor injury at the scene.
An unknown assailant shot and injured an unidentified 17-year-old girl on campus. Law enforcement has not identified a suspect in the shooting, has made no arrests, and does not have any suspects.

A thirty-eight-year-old fired shots at an unidentified female with whom he was an acquaintance, but did not injure her, and then fatally shot himself. The day before the shooting, the shooter was arrested for entering another woman’s home without permission. The student was not identified by the press.

During lunch at Rosemary Anderson High School, a student, 16, shot one person twice in the abdomen, a teen, 16, in the chest and abdomen, another teen, 17, in the upper back, and a teen, 17, in her left heel. The shooter was arrested and convicted of attempted murder, first-degree assault, second-degree assault and unlawful use of a firearm. Two others were also convicted in connection to with incident.

An unknown assailant shot and killed a 20-year-old inside a vehicle in the parking lot of the school. The victim lived across the street from the school. Law enforcement has not determined the identity of the assailant, and has made no arrests.

A 41-year-old fatally shot himself in the parking lot of the school. The incident occurred after school administrators saw an unfamiliar car in the parking lot and approached the vehicle. The administrators said that it appeared that the man inside the vehicle was under the influence of an unknown substance and called law enforcement. When law enforcement arrived, the shooter retrieved a .38-caliber handgun from inside the car and fatally shot himself.

A parent of a student at the school shot and injured a 15-year-old student and a teacher after an altercation in the parking lot. The shooter was arrested on the scene and later pleaded guilty to first degree reckless injury, use of a dangerous weapon, and felon in possession of a firearm. He was sentenced to six years in prison.

A man shot and injured an unidentified 14-year-old girl in the parking lot of the school. Law enforcement later arrested the man and charged him with two counts of aggravated battery with a deadly weapon.

School name: Royal Live Oaks Academy of the Arts and Sciences Charter School
Narrative: A male student was walking through a parking lot behind Royal Live Oaks Academy with two adults when he fired a handgun into the air once before fleeing the scene. The school was placed on partial lockdown, though no injuries were reported. The boy was arrested shortly thereafter without further incident, and charged with discharging a weapon on school property, carrying weapons on school property and carrying or displaying a firearm in a public building or adjacent areas.

An unidentified 48-year-old man fired a shot into the school's kitchen window before fatally shooting himself in the school's parking lot. Two school staff members were in the kitchen at the time of the shooting, but they were not injured. They alerted law enforcement, who found the man in a vehicle in the school's parking lot, dead of a self-inflicted gunshot wound. The man was not identified by the press.

Intent: Self-harm - no intent to hurt others
Narrative: A twenty-seven-year-old man shot himself in the library. Police had received a report that there was a potentially suicidal male on campus, but when they arrived and found the man, he fatally shot himself.
Two men, 21 and 19, shot and injured two students on the school's campus during a junior varsity basketball game. They were later arrested and charged.
A forty-six-year-old woman fatally shot her ex-husband, a professor, before fatally shooting herself in an academic building where he worked.

A twenty-one-year-old, the president of the fraternity Tau Kappa Epsilon, fired a shot into the air and then pointed the handgun at two Pi Kappa Alpha fraternity members. The incident occurred after a verbal confrontation between members of the two fraternities. No one was injured during the incident. The shooter was charged with two counts of aggravated assault and possession of a firearm on school grounds.

A 62-year-old shot and wounded two males in the parking lot of the school. Law enforcement reported that the shooter was related to the two victims and that the incident was a result of ongoing problems between them.

A 17-year old male fatally shot a 16-year-old in the parking lot of the school. The shooter was later arrested by police, along with a 20-year-old, who police believe drove the car used during the shooting.
An unknown assailant shot and injured three male students in a parking lot on campus. Law enforcement did not apprehend the assailant.

A 34-year-old man was shot in the elementary school parking lot after a dispute with two other men. He was taken to a nearby hospital and treated for non-life threatening injuries. An after-school program was in session at the time. Police arrested one of the men in connection with the incident.

An unidentified 21-year-old student unintentionally shot and injured himself in the leg in the parking lot of the university. Law enforcement stated that he was cleaning his weapon and emptying it of ammunition when it unintentionally discharged.

A nineteen-year-old shot and injured a 20-year-old on campus near the cafeteria with a 9mm handgun. Law enforcement arrested the shooter and charged him with aggravated assault and possession of a weapon on school property, among other charges.

A twenty-five-year-old fired a .40-caliber handgun into the air in the middle of campus. Nobody was injured during the incident and police apprehended and charged the shooter — a convicted felon — with unlawful gun possession.

A twenty-year-old man fatally shot a 44-year-old man with a shotgun in the school library. Law enforcement apprehended the shooter and charged him with murder. The victim was an openly gay man and the shooter admitted that he "hates gays with a passion."

Intent: Self-harm - no intent to hurt others
Narrative: An eighteen-year-old fatally shot himself on campus. He was found beside a tree between two campus buildings and was airlifted to a hospital where he was pronounced dead.
Following a fight during a Greek Cookout event at the center of campus, an unknown assailant pulled out a handgun and shot and injured three individuals.

An unknown person fired a gun into the ceiling while sitting in a university-run apartment at the University Courtyard Complex. The bullet lodged itself in the wall, and no one was injured during the incident. The shooter then fled the scene.

After being turned away from a campus party because they were not students, four men returned with several guns. Two of the men then fired the weapons randomly into the air, and a stray bullet hit a student while he was sitting in his car. The assailants fled the scene in a vehicle, and police pursued and apprehended them shortly thereafter. Prosecutors charged two of the men with discharging a firearm on school property. Another man, 21, was additionally charged with assault with a deadly weapon. A third man was charged with possession of a firearm by a convicted felon.

Law enforcement arrested an unidentified 11-year-old male student after a .45-caliber gun located in the student’s backpack discharged in a classroom. The student was charged with one count of possession of a stolen gun and one count of discharging a gun at a school, among other charges. No one was injured.

A 16-year-old student fired two shots with a handgun inside the school. He fired one shot into the ceiling of a second-floor hallway, and then fired a second shot into the ceiling of a common area. Someone restrained the student until law enforcement arrived to arrest the student. The student stated he had no intent to injure anyone else but was not identified by the press.

An unidentified male student unintentionally shot another 25-year-old student with a handgun in an academic building. The 23-year-old wanted to disassemble his gun to showcase the firearm's features. When he pulled the trigger, the bullet grazed the 25-year-old's chest and he was taken to the hospital where he underwent minor surgery. No charges were filed.

An unknown person fatally shot a 22-year-old and shot and injured an unidentified 26-year-old man on the playground during a drive-by shooting. The person was not apprehended and law enforcement does not have suspects.

A 14-year-old male student brought a gun to school and discharged it in the boy’s bathroom. There were no injuries, and police do not believe the shot was fired with the intent to harm anyone. The school was placed on temporary lockdown.

Intent: Self-harm - no intent to hurt others
Narrative: An eighteen-year-old fatally shot himself in the head on campus. A school resource officer saw the the student standing with a gun to his head, and when he tried to talk to the student, he shot himself.

Intent: Self-harm - no intent to hurt others
Narrative: Shortly after classes began, an 18-year-old fatally shot himself in his vehicle in the school parking lot.

Two men shot and injured seven unidentified people in the parking lot of the school. One man was charged with two counts of assault with intent to murder among other charges, and the other was charged with carrying a concealed weapon and possession of marijuana on school property.

A fifty-six-year-old man shot and injured another man, 30, in the hand. When law enforcement arrived, Daniels Jr. stated that he and Galloway had gotten into an argument that led to gunfire. Law enforcement located the shooter and charged him with aggravated battery and discharging a firearm on school property.

A thirty-eight-year-old man and a 39-year-old woman were arrested for firing a weapon on campus. They fatally shot a stray cat but did not injure any students or teachers. Law enforcement charged the man with attempted murder in the first-degree and discharge of a firearm on educational property, and the woman was charged with attempted murder in the first-degree and discharge of a firearm on educational property, among other charges.

A 32-year-old man fired approximately nine shots into another vehicle in the school parking lot after the individuals in that vehicle tried to rob the shooter during a drug deal. No one was injured. The shooter pleaded guilty to unlawful discharge of a firearm and two first-degree attempted assault charges.

Hundreds of people were attending a basketball tournament at Rawson School when a man, 34, got into a dispute with another man that escalated into gunfire, hitting innocent bystanders. The shooter, who was on probation for a 2011 conviction for carrying a pistol without a permit, drew a pistol and opened fire, killing a man, 41, and injuring two others. The shooter was also injured in the leg by an unknown shooter. The shooter was arrested and convicted of first-degree manslaughter with a firearm.

A man, 28, ran away from officers during a traffic stop across the street from John Jay High School. He took off on foot onto the campus and was run down by an undercover officer. A handgun fell out of his waistband, and the officer fired three rounds at the man, who was pronounced dead at the scene.

An eighteen-year-old man shot and injured another 18-year-old man while he was playing on the basketball court of the school. The shooter exited a vehicle, took out a handgun, and shot and injured the victim in the arm. The following day, law enforcement arrested the shooter at his home and charged him with aggravated assault, among other charges.

A 15-year-old shot and killed a 19-year-old while trying to rob the victim during a drug deal in the school parking lot. The 15-year-old was also shot in the arm during the incident. He was found guilty of murder and sentenced to life in prison.

A twenty-five-year-old man fired a handgun in the parking lot of a dorm during an argument. The man and his girlfriend, 21, were walking back from a bar to the parking lot when a fight broke out. The man fired a shot into the ground, but did not injure anyone. He was charged with discharging a firearm on school property and discharging a firearm while intoxicated, among other charges. His girlfriend was charged with carrying a concealed weapon.

A twenty-three-year-old man fatally shot another man, 23, in the parking lot of a dorm on campus. The victim had argued with a prostitute over the price for her services. When they could not agree, the shooter, who was the prostitute's pimp, beat the prostitute and then shot the victim. Both the shooter and the prostitute were charged in connection with the shooting.

A twenty-one- year-old man drove erratically toward the athletic fields of Paradise High School during cross-country and football practices of the high school student athletes. He reportedly stopped near concession stands on the field, held up a pistol and fired a shot out the window of his vehicle and then drove away. He did not injure anyone when he fired the shot. Law enforcement located the shooter in his vehicle and charged him with unlawful carrying of a weapon and deadly conduct. The Wise County Sheriff additionally stated to the media that investigators believe that alcohol was a factor in the incident. The sheriff confirmed that the shooter was on school property when he fired the gun. A search of Texas records yields no evidence that the shooter was prohibited from possessing firearms.

A twenty-year-old man fired a handgun from the roof of William Velasquez Elementary School. According to law enforcement, the shooter climbed onto the roof of the school and fired several rounds at school equipment. Police arrived and arrested the shooter and charged him with trespassing, and possession of a stolen firearm among other charges. The handgun the shooter used was reported stolen to the Sheriff's office after the incident. During a press conference, police reported that the shooter claimed he found the gun on nearby train tracks the night prior to the shooting. The shooter has previous misdemeanor drug arrests, but has never been convicted of a misdemeanor or felony. Police confirmed that the shooter was not affiliated with the school.

An unidentified third grade male student brought a gun to school. While playing with the gun inside the desk, the student unintentionally discharged the weapon and the shots injured a female student in his class. The student who brought the weapon got it from his grandmother's boyfriend, who was later charged with contributing to the delinquency of a minor. The injured student was transported to the hospital to be treated for non-life threatening injuries.

A man, 20, shot two students in the parking lot of a dormitory during an argument. A man, 24, died two days after the shooting and a woman, 26, was shot and injured. A TSU police officer witnessed the shooting and shot at the shooter twice, but did not hit him.

During an altercation, an unknown person shot a 20-year-old student on the Savannah State campus. The victim was transported to the hospital and died the following day. As of August 28th, 2015, law enforcement have not made any arrests.

A man 25, and another man, 23, got into a fight with two other men, both 19, on the campus of City College. The 23-year old stabbed one of the 19-year-olds, who survived. The othe 19-year-old fatally shot the 25-year-old, and a bullet grazed the 23-year-old. The 19-year-olds were subsequently convicted by a jury for the murder of of the 25-year-old.

At approximately 9:30 p.m., two people fired shots from a vehicle into the parking lot of Northside High School, hitting injuring an unidentified 17-year-old girl in the arm, who had just exited the football stadium with her friends. The group heard gunshots and was fleeing the area when a bullet hit the girl in the right arm; the others were not injured. Law enforcement described the shooters as two young black men, but as of September 14, 2015, they had not ben apprehended.
A forty-five-year-old man shot his girlfriend, 41, in her home. Twenty-five minutes later, he fatally shot a professor, 50, in an academic building and then proceeded to shoot himself off-campus.

A woman, 26, shot her estranged husband in the parking lot of their child's school after picking the child up. The sheriff said that the principal of the school stayed with the woman after she fled to the school, kept her in an office, and tried to calm her down until law enforcement arrived. When law enforcement arrived, they arrested her and transported her husband to the hospital.

A 21-year-old Montana Tech student was cleaning a firearm when he unintentionally discharged a round into the floor of his university-owned apartment. No one was physically harmed. The incident occurred in a 60-unit building that provides housing for students, families, faculty and staff, according to the Dean of Students. Campus security sent a report of the unintentional discharge to the Butte-Silver Bow County Attorney’s Office to review for possible charges. The name of the student was not released.

A 16-year-old student, shot and injured the school principal in the arm at the school. The school was placed on lockdown and law enforcement apprehended Buhl. Law enforcement confirmed that no one else was injured in this incident. The shooter later pleaded guilty to attempted murder and was committed to a mental health treatment facility.

A man, 26, shot and killed nine people in a creative writing class at Umpqua Community College, and shot and injured seven additional people. After a brief exchange of gunfire with police, during which he was injured, the man shot and killed himself.

A seventeen-year-old brought a .38-caliber handgun to school. According to press, he obtained the firearm from an unidentified friend off-campus. He was showing it to his friend, 17, in the school restroom, when the 17-year-old unintentionally fired the weapon into the floor. No one was physically injured. A school security guard heard the shot and called law enforcement, who arrested both students. They were charged with unlawful use of a weapon. Because both students are under 18, they were prohibited from possessing handguns.

At approximately 10:15 p.m., a man, 19, shot and injured another person 19, twice in the stomach on campus near the recreation center after an argument, and then fled. Law enforcement stated that the victim was not a student at the school and was attending an event on campus. They confirmed that the shooter was previously enrolled at the school but was not a current student this semester. As of October 8, 2015, law enforcement have not apprehended the shooter.

At approximately 1:20 am, a man, 18, shot and killed one man, 20 and shot and injured three other men, all 20. The shooting took place near a dormitory that houses most of the campus' students involved in Greek organizations. It is not yet determined whether the shooter and victims were students of the school. Law enforcement arrested the shooter.

At approximately 11:30 a.m., a man, 19, fatally shot one man and injured another. The University spokesperson confirmed that the shooting occurred at the University Courtyard Apartment Complex on the edge of the campus. Law enforcement arrested the shooter and charged him with murder. The school confirmed this shooting occurred on school owned property.

At approximately 4:00 a.m., a man, 21, fired a .45 caliber handgun from a campus parking garage, which hit the exterior of a residence building. Law enforcement responded to the campus after reports of gunfire and found the student in his dorm room with the firearm. Law enforcement arrested the student and charged him with discharging a firearm on campus. The University issued a statement that indicated the student was immediately suspended from all team activities.

At 9:15 a.m., a woman 22, used a handgun to shoot out the back window of the Wagner High School principal's car, parked in the school parking lot. She also reportedly hit the car multiple times with a baseball bat. No one was in the car during the shooting, and no injuries were reported. A district spokesperson said the principal had recently reprimanded an unidentified student for a t-shirt he wore to school, and that the shooter, a friend of the student, shot the car in retaliation. She was arrested in her home later that afternoon and charged with deadly conduct and possession of a firearm in a school zone.

Following a concert at the Student Success Center during homecoming, an unidentified man fired two shots into the air. No injuries were reported. Campus police witnessed the shooting and immediately arrested the man, who was not a student at the school. He was charged with possessing and discharging a weapon on campus.

After an argument over a late-evening dice game, an unknown man shot and killed a 19-year-old man in a school courtyard and shot and injured three 18-year-old female students who were walking nearby. None of the victims were immediately publicly identified. According to a police statement, the male victim was not currently enrolled at the college. Two of the women were treated at a local hospital for non-life threatening injuries and released early the following morning, and the third was grazed and did not require medical attention. The shooter fled the scene.

During a drug deal in the school parking lot, a man 18, shot another man 25, while the victim was sitting in a car with a friend. The victim's friend drove him to a nearby hospital, where he was pronounced dead. The shooter was later sentenced to 45 years in prison; two accomplices were sentenced to 20 years in prison each.

Shortly after 11:00 p.m., an unknown person shot and injured a student who was not publicly identified near the edge of campus, as well as shooting out the window of a campus dormitory. The student was taken to a local hospital with non-life threatening injuries. A university spokesman announced that campus police were investigating the shooting, and that no arrests had been made.

Shortly after midnight, a man, 21, a former student, shot and killed a 19-year-old sophomore as the victim walked home from the homecoming masquerade ball, and shot and injured another unidentified student. The victim was pronounced dead at the scene by emergency services, and the other student was taken to a local hospital with non-life threatening injuries. The shooter was arrested by campus police after a brief pursuit, and charged with murder and possession of a weapon on school grounds.

A 10-year-old student attempted to throw a chair at his teacher during class, and was then forcibly removed from the classroom by an armed police officer. While being escorted out, the student hit the police officer in his belt, discharging the officer's handgun, firing into the floor. No injuries were reported. Moultrie Police announced they were not planning to file charges against the boy.

Intent: Self-harm - no intent to hurt others
Narrative: During his morning English class, a 15-year-old boy walked to the front of the classroom, pulled out his father's 9mm semi-automatic handgun, and shot himself in the head in an attempted suicide. The boy was able to briefly speak with school resource officers before being airlifted to an area hospital in stable condition.

While sitting in a parked car in the school lot, waiting for the school bus to arrive, a junior high school student took out a .357-caliber handgun to show his friend. He then unintentionally discharged the gun, shooting his friend in the leg. The injured boy was taken to an area hospital with non-life threatening injuries. The Independence County Sheriff's Department noted that the boy who fired the gun was expected to face school discipline, but not criminal charges.

Intent: Self-harm - no intent to hurt others
Narrative: After vandalizing a number of paintings on the upper level of the Wexner Center for the Arts, a college-run art gallery and classroom space, a man, 63, a former college security officer, shot and killed himself with a handgun. No other injuries were reported.

During an argument between two men near a dormitory after a high school basketball game, one of them pulled out a handgun and fired multiple shots in the air in an attempt to scare the other. A campus security officer witnessed the shooting and chased both men off campus. Jackson Police announced they were investigating the incident, but did not immediately have any suspects.

Intent: Self-harm - no intent to hurt others
Narrative: Shortly after 7:00 a.m., an unidentified man shot and killed himself while sitting in the front seat of his car in the Aims Community College parking lot. He was pronounced dead at the scene by emergency services. The Weld County Sheriff's Office did not immediately know if the man had a connection to the college.

A twelve-year-old boy took his father's .380-caliber handgun from home and gave it to his friend, a 13-year-old student, at school. The 13-year-old then discharged the gun while playing with it in a school bathroom, hitting a toilet. The school was placed on lockdown for an hour, and the boys were both taken into custody by local police and charged with theft of a firearm and possession of a firearm in a school zone, among other charges.

Three students were examining a handgun in a car outside of their high school when a 17-year-old boy discharged the gun. The bullet went through the driver's seat, hitting an 18-year-old boy in his back. The older boy was taken to a local hospital and treated for non-life threatening injuries. The younger boy was arrested and charged in juvenile court.

As an unidentified school employee arrived at work in the morning, he went to lock his handgun in his car's glove compartment while parked in the school lot. He then unintentionally discharged the gun, shooting through a window in the car. Indianapolis Police announced the man was licensed to carry the handgun, and that licensed school employees are allowed the have a gun locked in a car on campus, and therefore no charges would be filed.

Following a basketball game, a 17-year-old teen shot and injured a 15-year-old boy in their high school parking lot. The boys, both students, were arguing throughout the game, and as they left the gymnasium, the shooter pulled out a handgun and shot the younger boy twice in the leg. He was taken to a local hospital and treated for non-life threatening injuries. The shooter was turned in to police by his mother, and charged with criminal recklessness with a firearm and possession of a handgun without a license on school property. Indianapolis Police announced they were investigating the incident, and were not immediately sure how the boy obtained the firearm.

During a transition period in between classes shortly before noon, three boys got into an argument on a stairwell. A 16-year-old boy pulled out a handgun and fired one shot at another boy, missing him and hitting a stairwell. After a brief lockdown, all three boys were arrested by a responding SWAT team. Philadelphia Police announced they were investigating the incident, and were not immediately sure how the boy came to possess the handgun.

After being denied entrance to a high school basketball game, a group of 10-12 teenagers started fighting in a parking lot outside of the gym. During the fight, a man, 21, pulled out a handgun and shot and injured two unidentified female students and an unidentified male. The shooter then brandished his weapon at a sheriff's deputy, who shot the shooter three times. The shooter later pleaded no contest to several charges from the shooting and was sentenced to prison.

Shortly before the start of the school day, a 15-year-old girl shot and killed her girlfriend of two years, also 15, in a hallway by a cafeteria before shooting and killing herself. Emergency services declared both girls dead at the scene. The shooter had asked a male classmate to steal the gun for her from his father, saying she needed it for protection.

Shortly after 8 a.m., a man's concealed handgun fell out through a hole in his shorts as he dropped his son off at school. A boy found the handgun inside the school's entranceway and reported it to a teacher. As a janitor attempted to secure the gun, he unintentionally fired it into a wall. No one was injured. Homosassa Police announced they were not planning to file charges against the owner of the gun.

During a high school basketball game, a 63-year-old man began arguing with his ex-girlfriend and her boyfriend, who were also attending the game. The three were then escorted from the game by a security guard. Shortly thereafter, while standing in the school parking lot, the 63-year-old man pulled out a handgun and shot the unidentified man once in the arm, and then struck his ex-girlfriend in the head with the end of the gun. The shooter was immediately arrested by a police officer who happened to be in the parking lot, and was charged with two counts of aggravated assault with a deadly weapon. He was sentenced to 20 years in prison.

Shortly after 10:00 a.m., a 14-year-old eighth grader walked into the school cafeteria during the eighth grade lunch period and fired at least six shots from a .380-caliber handgun, hitting two other students. The shooter then fled the scene through a wooded area by the school, where he also discarded the handgun. He was apprehended by responding police officers without further incident. The two shot and injured students were airlifted to an area hospital in stable condition. The Butler County Sheriff told reporters that neither students' injuries were considered life threatening. At least two other students were reportedly injured during the incident, by shrapnel or while trying to leave the cafeteria.

As school let out for the day, a man, 19, drove into the parking lot of a high school, got out of his car and fired multiple shots at a group of students walking towards the gym, grazing a 15-year-old boy in the head. A nearby police officer fired multiple shots in return but did not hit the shooter, who promptly put down his gun and surrendered. The injured student was taken to a local hospital and treated for non-life threatening injuries. The shooter was arrested and charged with attempted murder. According to press reports, he told police he was retaliating against a student who fought his younger brother earlier in the day.

During a drug deal in the parking lot outside of a dormitory, an 18-year-old freshman shot and injured a man, 19, as they sat in the victim's car, before the victim returned fire, shooting and injuring the shooter. Both men were taken to a local hospital in critical condition for treatment, where they were arrested and charged with assault, attempted murder, and possession of a firearm on campus.

While visiting a friend in his dorm room, two men, both non-students, got into an argument, and one of the men pulled out a handgun and shot the other in the leg before fleeing the scene. The victim was taken to a local hospital and treated for non-life threatening injuries. The shooter was arrested hours later without further incident. Charlotte Police did not immediately announce further details, citing an ongoing investigation. The student they were visiting was suspended indefinitely for violating the school's visitor and firearm possession policies.

Shortly before 3:00 a.m., two male students who were returning from a party were stopped outside of their dorm room by three masked men and robbed at gunpoint. One of the students started yelling at a robber, who pulled out a handgun and fired one shot in the air. The students then fled the scene and reported the incident to police. Neither student was injured. Tacoma Police announced they were investigating the incident.

Intent: Self-harm - no intent to hurt others
Narrative: Campus officials discovered a senior engineering student dead of an apparent self-inflicted gunshot wound to the head in his car outside of a dormitory.

Following an argument shortly before 4:00 a.m., a sophomore at the University fired at least two shots into a vehicle that two other unidentified students were sitting in, hitting both students, before fleeing the scene. Both of the injured students were taken to a local hospital and treated for non-life threatening injuries. The shooter turned himself into police later that afternoon, and was charged with two counts of attempted murder. There is no evidence the shooter was prohibited from possessing firearms at the time of the shooting.

At the Antigo High School prom, a former student of the school opened fire with a rifle he had purchased two weeks earlier. Two students, his ex-girlfriend and her prom date, were injured. Two law enforcement officers who were on patrol responded immediately and wounded the shooter, who later died at a hospital.

Police responded to the University of Central Florida after reports of a gun on campus. After the search concluded, an officer went to secure his rifle in the gun rack in the vehicle and it discharged. No one was injured.

During a swim lesson at the campus pool, an unidentified parent unintentionally discharged a .40-caliber handgun he was holding in his back pocket while standing on the pool deck, hitting the tile deck. No injuries were reported. Charleston Police announced they were investigating the incident, and that the man was licensed to carry a concealed firearm at the time of the incident.

During class, a 15-year-old boy unintentionally discharged a revolver that he had in his back pocket, hitting himself in the leg and hand. He was taken to a local hospital and treated for serious but non-life threatening injuries. Dallas Police announced they were investigating the incident, and that it was not immediately clear why the student had brought the gun to school. A school administrator said that the boy had arrived at school late, and was therefore not subject to the metal detectors normally at the entrances.

Just after school was let out for the day, a man, 25, drove into the school's rear parking lot, called out the name of a teacher, and began firing shots, injuring her. He then fled the scene. Police later found him in his car with a self-inflicted gunshot wound.

As a 44-year-old woman waited in a parking lot outside of her children's high school to pick them up after school, her estranged husband drove up and starting arguing with her. Another parent, who was not immediately identified, approached the couple in an attempt to defuse the argument. As the man approached, the husband drew a handgun and shot the man once in the chest, before turning and shooting his wife at least three times in the chest and the head. The shooter then fled the scene. The woman was pronounced dead at the scene by emergency responders, while the unidentified man was taken to a local hospital and treated for critical but non-life threatening injuries. The shooter was subject to a protective order by the victim at the time of the shooting, and was prohibited from possessing firearms.

During an end-of-year celebration at the school's main quadrangle, an unidentified male fired two shots from a handgun into the air before fleeing the scene. No injuries were reported. Columbia Police announced they were investigating the incident.

During a morning class, a 14-year-old boy reached into his backpack and unintentionally discharged one of two handguns he was keeping inside of the backpack, hitting a table leg. No injuries were reported, and the school was not placed on lockdown. The boy was arrested and charged with unlawful possession of a firearm, altering the serial number on a firearm, possessing a firearm on school property and unlawful discharge of a firearm. Twin Falls Police announced they were investigating the incident.

During a job interview, an unidentified man unintentionally discharged a .22-caliber handgun he was carrying, hitting himself in the knee. He was taken to a local hospital and treated for non-life threatening injuries. The man is a part-time corrections officer, and was licensed to carry the gun. Panama City Police announced they did not expect to file charges.

Three men, 21, 17, and 18, were attempting to rob a student inside of a dormitory when the 21-year-old fired a shot from a .45-caliber handgun into the ceiling, attempting to scare the victim of their robbery attempt. No injuries were reported. All three men were arrested the following evening and charged with criminal possession of a controlled substance and weapon. The 21-year-old was also charged with reckless endangerment. He pleaded guilty to first-degree robbery and was sentenced to five years in prison.

A 16-year-old boy unintentionally shot himself using a gun brought to school by another student, 17. The boy was taken to a local hospital and treated for non-life threatening injuries. The boy’s father said the boy and his classmate had conspired to bring the gun to school for protection after a teacher allegedly made sexual advances towards one of them. The classmate, the boy who was shot, and two other juveniles face charges from the incident.

During a graduation ceremony at the school football field, a parent reached down to adjust his gun, which was in his sock. He unintentionally discharged the firearm. The bullet went through the man's foot and hit a nearby woman in the calf. Both people were taken to a local hospital and treated for serious but non-life threatening injuries. The man was licensed to carry the firearm, but Augusta Police confirmed to reporters that a sign posted outside of the football field prohibited the possession of firearms inside the stadium. The District Attorney's Office announced they were investigating the incident.
A University of Texas police officer unintentionally shot himself in the leg while in a campus parking lot.

A former doctoral student, 38, shot and killed his engineering professor, 39, before shooting and killing himself in the professor's office. Prior to traveling to LA to kill the professor, the shooter had shot and killed his estranged wife in Minnesota.

As he sat in his car preparing to give a product demonstration at the University of Missouri, a smoothie vendor unintentionally discharged his handgun while moving it to the glove compartment, hitting himself in the leg. He was treated at the university hospital for non-life threatening injuries. Columbia Police announced that charges would not be filed against the man.

While cleaning his handgun in a janitorial office, a 32-year-old school janitor unintentionally discharged the gun, hitting himself in the hand. The campus was locked down while police investigated the incident. The janitor drove himself to a local hospital and treated for non-life threatening injuries. He was arrested and charged with bringing a gun to campus and carrying an unregistered, loaded gun.

During a standoff that resulted in the death of five police officers, and the shooting injury of nine officers and two civilians, a man, 25, retreated to the second-floor hallway of El Centro College, where he exchanged gunfire with officers for several hours. One officer was injured by the man's gunfire while on campus (an El Centro College officer), and one officer was killed (a Dallas Police Sgt.) and another wounded (a DART officer) by the shooter's gunfire while he fired shots from campus. Students at the college were sheltered in place overnight and evacuated in the morning. The shooter was also injured by gunfire during the conflict, was then killed when officers detonated a bomb in the hallway.

Two 18-year-old boys who recently graduated from high school together met in the school parking lot to fight in a dispute about a girl. One of the boys pulled out a handgun and shot the other in the chest, and then shot and killed himself. The victim was taken to a local hospital and placed in intensive care. Ava Police announced they were investigating the incident, and did not immediately announce how the shooter acquired the handgun.

As part of an active shooter drill for school staff and faculty at Rockwood Middle School, officers were firing blank rounds in a school hallway. One officer unintentionally fired a live round during the drill. No one was injured.

Shortly before midnight, an unknown person fired two shots at a Northeast Mississippi Community College student from their car while the student was jogging across campus, hitting him once in the back of the leg. The student was taken to a local hospital and treated for non-life threatening injuries.

School name: McLain High School for Science and Tech
Narrative: During the final minutes of a high school football game, a 16-year-old student and a 13-year-old student got into a verbal argument in the stands. The older boy then pulled out a handgun and shot the younger boy once in the head, grazing his temple. The younger boy was taken to a local hospital and treated for serious but non-life threatening injuries. The older boy fled the scene and was apprehended hours later. Tulsa Police announced they were investigating the incident, and did not immediately announce further details, citing the ages of the boys involved.

School name: Detroit Collegiate Preparatory High School at Northwestern
Narrative: The principal of Detroit Collegiate Preparatory High School at Northwestern was pulling into the parking lot when someone opened fire on his vehicle. Additional shots were fired as he exited his vehicle and ran to safety inside the school building, one of which struck the vehicle and shattered the rear driver's side window. No injuries were reported, and police were looking for a former student as a suspect.

Shortly after 8:00 a.m., an unidentified student shot and injured another female student in the school's band room, hitting her multiple times, before shooting and killing herself. The injured girl was taken to a local hospital in serious condition. While responding to the incident, a marshal unintentionally fired his gun, injuring a Homeland Security agent, who was treated for non-life threatening injuries.

As two men, neither of whom were immediately identified, were arguing in a campus parking lot, one man pulled out a handgun and shot the other man once in the leg, before fleeing the scene. The injured man was taken to a local hospital and treated for non-life threatening injuries, and the shooter was apprehended by campus police without further incident. Alabama State Police announced they were investigating the incident, and noted that neither man was a current student at the University.

Intent: Self-harm - no intent to hurt others
Narrative: Just before Cedar Rapids Jefferson High School opened at 8:00 a.m., an unidentified 15-year-old male student shot himself in the head outside of the school gym. He was transported to a local hospital with life-threatening injuries, and died three days later. The school was briefly locked down, but police noted that there was no threat to other students during the incident.
A student unintentionally fired his handgun inside of his dorm room, hitting the ceiling. No injuries were reported. The student was reportedly licensed to carry the firearm on campus.

A 13-year-old student was shot and injured after becoming “uncooperative” while reporting an earlier incident. The child allegedly “tugged” on an officer’s belt, purportedly causing the officer’s holstered weapon to discharge and graze the child’s arm.

After shooting and killing his father outside their home, a boy 14, drove a truck into the school parking lot. The boy then shot two six-year-olds and a teacher. The boy was tackled by an off-duty firefighter who was nearby and held without further incident until law enforcement arrived. One of the six-year-olds was taken to a local hospital and died three days after the shooting. The other six-year-old and the teacher were treated for serious but non-life threatening injuries. The boy had planned to use his father's semi-automatic weapon but was not able to access his father's gun safe, where he believed the gun was stored.

During a JV football game, two unidentified men started arguing in the parking lot outside of the game. One of the men pulled out a handgun and fired at least 12 shots, hitting the other man multiple times, before fleeing the scene. The injured man was taken to a local hospital in stable condition. Fort Worth Police announced they were investigating the incident. The rest of the football game was cancelled following the incident.

Shortly after school let out for the day, a teen, 16, approached a male student as the student crossed a parking lot towards the school's baseball tryouts. The teen shot the boy once in the stomach before fleeing the scene. The injured student was taken to a local hospital and treated for non-life threatening injuries. The teen was apprehended and charged with attempted murder.

Two students, 12 and 15, were shot on the front lawn of Linden McKinley STEM Academy during a drive-by shooting. Both were sent to the hospital in stable condition. The shooter, 17, was sentenced to eight years in prison.
After a football game at Benjamin Elijah Mays High School, an unidentified individual in a car entered the school parking lot and shot a student, injuring him.

School name: June Jordan High School for Equity
Narrative: Four individuals entered the school parking lot and opened fire on a student using pistols and air guns. Four 15-year-old students — one female, the intended target, and three males — were hit by bullets and sustained injures.

During a fight between six people, including two students, inside of a dorm room at 2:30 a.m., a man, 23, fired a handgun multiple times at the wall. One bullet passed through the wall and struck a freshman who was asleep in the next room over, in the hand. The freshman was taken to a local hospital and treated for non-life threatening injuries. The shooter was charged with multiple offenses and sentenced to prison.

Shortly before midnight, an unidentified student fired multiple shots from a handgun outside of a dormitory, hitting the building. No injuries were reported. The student was arrested without further incident the following morning. Huntsville Police announced they were investigating the incident.

During an after-school confrontation on campus, a 14-year-old shot a 16-year-old twice in the head and neck. The victim was taken to a hospital with serious injuries. Police arrested the 14-year-old and charged him with attempted murder, discharge of a firearm causing serious injury, discharge of a firearm, and possession of a gun on school property.

Intent: Self-harm - no intent to hurt others
Narrative: Shortly before school let out in the afternoon, a student, 17, took his own life using a firearm in a car in the student parking lot.

Intent: Self-harm - no intent to hurt others
Narrative: A fifteen-year-old student shot and killed himself in a hallway at his high school shortly before school opened in the morning. Berthoud Police declined to immediately release further details.

A Sheriff's Deputy, 51, unintentionally discharged his weapon while using a force machine to test the trigger pull. He was assigned to the school as a resource officer. The bullet went through the wall and struck a teacher in the neck. The man initially lied about the shooting and tried to destroy evidence. He was sentenced to 30 days in jail.

An unidentified seven-year-old first grader brought a handgun to school and discharged it inside his backpack, hitting a wall. No injuries were reported. St. Paul police announced they were investigating the incident, and did not immediately disclose how the student came to possess the handgun.
A man plowed his car into a campus crowd and stabbed people with a knife, sending 11 to a nearby hospital with non-life threatening injuries. He was fatally shot by a police officer.

An unidentified 15-year-old boy entered a morning science class, armed with his father's shotgun, and fired a single shot into the ceiling of the classroom. The boy's mother, who had chased him into the classroom, then grabbed the gun and held the boy down, before pulling him into the hall. No injuries were reported. Bountiful Police announced they were investigating the incident, and did not immediately file charges.

A boy, 14, began brandishing a pair of knives during a fight with another student. A school district officer commanded him to drop them, and then, when the boy ignored the order, fired a single shot. The boy sustained serious injuries. Police launched an investigation into the incident.

During a high school basketball game, three men confronted another individual and began arguing. One of the men, 17, then pulled out a gun and shot the individual in the shoulder. The shooter was arrested several months later and charged with armed criminal action, assault and unlawful use of a weapon.

A man, 25, shot and killed his wife while sitting in their car in a parking lot at the University of Utah, before shooting and killing himself. Both worked in a laboratory affiliated with the university. Salt Lake City Police announced they were investigating the incident.

Intent: Self-harm - no intent to hurt others
Narrative: Shortly before 2:00 p.m., a 20-year-old student at the Warren County Career Center Vocational School shot and killed himself in the school's parking lot. No other injuries were reported.

An unidentified student was showing another student a handgun in his backpack, when he unintentionally discharged the gun while reaching to grab it. The gun fired through the backpack and hit the floor - no injuries were reported. A school resource officer recovered the gun and took both students into custody.

During student pick-up after school, a parent unintentionally discharged his handgun while sitting in his car, shooting through the floor of the car. No injuries were reported. The Franklin County Sheriff's Office announced they were investigating the incident.

A woman, 29, shot a 34-year-old protestor in the abdomen outside a university auditorium where Milo Yiannopoulos was appearing. One person was critically injured and required several surgeries. The woman was later charged with first-degree assault. Her husband was charged with third-degree assault after prosecutors determined the couple had created the situation deliberately.

A teen, 17, shot and injured a 16-year-old teen in the bathroom of their high school, before he was apprehended by school faculty. The victim, who was hit multiple times with a shotgun, was taken to a local hospital in critical condition for surgery, but was expected to survive. The shooter was arrested and charged with attempted murder, assault, and other charges.

An unidentified 19-year-old student unintentionally discharged a handgun he was carrying inside his dorm room, hitting himself in the leg. He was taken to a local hospital and treated for non-life threatening injuries. Campus police announced they were investigating the incident.

Following a high school basketball game, as the crowd filed into the parking lot, a man, 18, fired multiple shots from the parking lot at the crowd, striking three people: a 13-year-old female student, a 19-year-old man, and a 45-year-old woman. All three were taken to a local hospital and treated for non-life threatening injuries. The shooter fled the scene, but was later apprehended and charged with multiple offenses, including three counts of attempted murder. An additional suspect was arrested and charged with carrying a pistol on school property and unlawful carrying of a pistol.

Following a fight in a hallway between classes, a 14-year-old student pulled out a handgun and fired multiple shots at other students, hitting a wall and a locker. No injuries were reported. The student fled the school and was arrested without further incident ten minutes later.
