He was charged with possession of a firearm on school property, illegal carry of a weapon, illegal use of a weapon, aggravated assault, aggravated criminal damage to property, and attempted second degree murder.
After kidnapping his estranged fiancée, a 32-year-old man drove to Maplewood Middle School and shot himself in the head in the school's parking lot. He was taken to a hospital and pronounced dead.

During an alleged string of armed robberies inside of a residence hall, an unidentified male discharged a handgun while threatening a student. The bullet passed through two walls and hit another student, who was sitting in her dorm room, in the leg. The injured student was taken to a local hospital and treated for non-life threatening injuries. The shooter fled the scene, and local and campus police announced they were investigating the incident.
A man was arguing with several men in a parking lot outside an athletic center when he fired at least one shot into the air. No one was injured. The man was arrested a few days after the shooting.

A man, 23, went to Linton Middle School to play basketball with three friends. In the parking lot, before getting out of the car, he was confronted by a teen, 16, who climbed into the back seat to rob him with a handgun. The teen struck the man, and then jumped out of the vehicle and fired a shot into the car door. Before driving away, the man then fired at the teen and fatally hit him. A court later found the man guilty of carrying a gun on school property and tampering with evidence. He was not charged for shooting the teen.

During an argument at the school's outdoor basketball courts, an unknown person fired three shots at a group of students before fleeing the scene. No injuries were reported, and a suspect was not immediately identified. Pensacola Police announced they were investigating the incident.

A student unintentionally discharged a handgun inside of their dorm room, firing the bullet through the wall and hitting a student in the next room in the chest. The injured student was taken to a local hospital in critical condition for surgery, but was expected to survive. St. Paul Police announced they were investigating the incident. The University prohibits all weapons on school property.

A man, 53, shot and killed his estranged wife in her classroom. The shooter walked into his wife's classroom and, without speaking, pulled out a concealed .357-caliber handgun and fired ten shots at her, hitting her multiple times in the head and chest. An eight-year-old student and a nine-year-old student were standing behind the victim at the time, and were both also shot. The shooter then shot and killled himself. Both the shooter and the victim were pronounced dead at the scene — the two students were airlifted to an area hospital in critical condition, where the eight-year-old boy was pronounced dead, and the injured student was treated for serious but non-life threatening injuries.

Following an argument at an alumni basketball game, a 53-year-old man shot and injured a man, 52, in the school parking lot, before fleeing the scene. The victim was taken to a local hospital in stable condition. The shooter was later charged with shooting with intent to kill.

While eating lunch in a campus cafeteria, an unidentified student reached into his backpack and unintentionally discharged a handgun he was carrying inside the backpack, hitting a table and a light fixture. No injuries were reported. The student, who was licensed to carry a concealed handgun on campus, was questioned and released without being charged. Campus police announced they were investigating the incident.

A former student, 21, shot and killed a 20-year-old woman in a study hall before moving to another building and fatally shooting himself. Both the shooter and the victim were pronounced dead at the scene. According to the victim's mother, the shooter had repeatedly stalked the victim prior to the shooting.

A first grader brought a handgun to his classroom in his backpack and it fell out of his backpack. A seven-year-old classmate picked up the gun and unintentionally discharged it, hitting another student. The injured student was taken to a local hospital for surgery. The first grader's father and older brother — the source of the weapon — were later indicted for negligent injuring.

Intent: Self-harm - no intent to hurt others
Narrative: After submitting his resignation, the Kirbyville High School Principal, 45, walked out to the school parking lot, got into the front seat of his car, and shot himself in the head. He was pronounced dead at the scene by emergency responders.

Following an argument, an unidentified 15-year-old student approached another student in the school bus loading zone, drew a .22-caliber handgun, and fired one shot at the student, missing him. A substitute teacher disarmed the student, who was taken into custody. No injuries were reported.

During an evening class, a 24-year-old man entered Ravenscroft Beauty College and shot two women, 29 and 20, before shooting and killing himself. The shooter was reportedly upset after the 29-year-old woman refused to date him. The 29-year-old woman was taken to an area hospital with critical injuries. The 20-year-old woman, who the 29-year-old woman shielded with her body during the shooting, was treated at a local hospital for non-life threatening injuries. The shooter was pronounced dead at the scene. He was previously convicted of felony burglary and spent four years in prison, and was likely prohibited from buying or possessing guns at the time of the shooting.

A teen, 18, and two unidentified boys, ages 16 and 17, opened fire on an elementary school picnic after they had been arguing with some other individuals who ran into the picnic. A girl, 13, and an unidentified 7-year-old were both shot. All three individuals face several charges from the shooting.

Two 17-year-old students were sitting in a car before school examining a handgun when one of the boys unintentionally discharged it, hitting himself in the foot. He was taken to a local hospital and treated for non-life threatening injuries. He was arrested and charged with carrying a weapon on school property, possession of a stolen handgun and providing false information to law enforcement.

A suspected serial carjacker fired several shots at a fleeing woman and her 11-year-old daughter on the University of Nevada - Las Vegas campus. According to police statements, the unidentified woman and her daughter attempted to drive away from the suspect, passing through the campus security complex and the center of campus, as he fired seven to nine shots at the fleeing car. No injuries were reported, and the campus was placed on lockdown. The suspect was arrested hours later without further incident.

Following an argument during a pickup basketball game at the Hickman Academy gym, an unidentified man retreived a handgun from his gym bag and shot a 32-year-old man multiple times in the chest and arms. The injured man was taken to a local hospital and treated for serious but non-life threatening injuries. The shooter fled the scene. Milwaukee Police announced they were investigating the incident.

During a fight in the Spanish Fork High School parking lot, a 19-year-old man shot and injured an 18-year-old man before fleeing the scene. The younger man was taken to a local hospital and treated for non-life threatening injuries.

During an argument in a parking lot on the University of Arkansas campus, an unidentified man pulled out a handgun and fired multiple shots into another car, hitting a 25-year-old man, a lineman for the Tennessee Titans, and a 22-year-old man. Both men were treated at a local hospital for non-life threatening injuries. Fayetteville Police announced they were investigating the incident.

Intent: Self-harm - no intent to hurt others
Narrative: A teacher, 43, shot himself in the head while alone in his office. He was able to call another teacher for help, and was airlifted to an area hospital in critical condition.

An unidentified student, who is a member of the Corps of Cadets, unintentionally discharged a handgun in his Corps dorm room, firing a bullet through a wall and hitting a bedframe in the next room. No injuries were reported. University and local police announced no charges were expected to be filed.

A former student, 19, was shot and injured while sitting in his car in a parking lot outside of a dorm. He was taken to a local hospital in critical condition. Tennessee State announced that the victim was not a student at the school, and Nashville Police announced they were investigating the incident.

A teen, 18, walked into his high school hallway and fired multiple shots into the floor, ceiling, and wall, yelling that he was looking for someone. A teacher was able to talk the student into putting the gun down, and he was taken into custody without further incident. No injuries were reported.

Following a football game during which several fights reportedly broke out in the stands, an unidentified person fired multiple shots in the school parking lot during another fight. Two ricocheted bullets hit one juvenile, who was taken to a local hospital and treated for non-life threatening injuries. The crowd dispersed before a suspect could be identified. North Little Rock Police announced they were investigating the incident.

A campus security guard, 25, unintentionally shot himself in the shoulder. He then called police and reported that a Black man had shot him, leading to a large manhunt on campus that involved K-9s and searches of campus buildings. Police later learned that the security guard had shot himself, and he pleaded guilty to falsely reporting a crime to the police.

Shortly after school opened for the day, a 15-year-old sophomore pulled an AR-15 rifle and a handgun from a duffel bag and began walking through the school hallway, firing multiple shots and hitting three female students who were fleeing. Another sophomore then approached the shooter and attempted to stop him from shooting -- the shooter shot him once in the head. The shooter's rifle then jammed, and before he could pull out his handgun, a custodian tackled the shooter and held him until police arrived. The three girls were taken to an area hospital in stable condition, and the other sophomore was pronounced dead at the scene. The shooter was taken into police custody.

Campus police responded to the Georgia Institute of Technology after receiving reports of a possibly armed person on campus. The person, a 21-year-old student at the university, was shot and killed by a responding officer.

During an argument in a campus parking lot shortly after midnight, an unidentified man left his car, walked up to another car, and fired one shot through the window, hitting an unidentified man sitting in the car. The injured man was taken to a local hospital and treated for non-life threatening injuries. The shooter fled the scene. Akron Police announced they were investigating the incident.

During lunchtime, an unidentified high school student opened fire in the cafeteria of Mattoon High School, injuring one other student. A nearby teacher disarmed the student, and the shooter was taken into custody. The injured student was taken to a local hospital in stable condition.

Intent: Self-harm - no intent to hurt others
Narrative: During the school day, a 17-year-old student shot herself in a hallway of the high school in an apparent suicide.  She was transported to a nearby hospital where she died of her injuries.
Late at night, a woman and her boyfriend were driving and having an argument.  They pulled over into the school parking lot where the woman shot her boyfriend in the leg, injuring him.

A teen, 18, allegedly punched a school administrator after he was accused of assaulting his ex-girlfriend. When police responded to the school, the teen attempted to grab one of the officer's firearms, causing it to discharge inside the school. No one was shot.
Around 4 AM, three young men were loitering outside Picacho Middle School when one fired two shots from a handgun damaging four of the school's windows.

After being arrested by campus police for possession of drug paraphernalia, a 19-year-old freshman opened fire on a Texas Tech police officer. The officer was hit in the head and died from his injuries. The shooter, who carried out the shooting in the police station, then fled the scene, causing the campus to go into lockdown for just over an hour. The Lubbock County Sheriff's Office captured the shooter and charged him with capital murder.

A man, 57, unintentionally discharged a gun in the college's plumber's shop, injuring another staff member in the leg. The shooter was subsequently fired by the college for bringing a weapon onto campus and faced criminal charges.

After a concert during homecoming weekend, a man was shot in the pelvis, sending the campus into lock down. Calling the shooting an "isolated incident," police lifted the lockdown at 1:30am, though no suspect was apprehended. The man's injuries were not life threatening.

During an attempted robbery, a man, 20, shot another man in the abdomen. A crowd of some 200 people was dispersed by police after the shooting as the campus went into lockdown for more than four hours. The shooter was eventually arrested and sentenced to 24 years in prison. The victim's injuries were not life-threatening, though he suffered damage to his colon and kidney.

After an argument in a dorm room, a man, 19, opened fire in the courtyard outside on another man, 23. When the victim's friend tried to help, the shooter shot him too. Both men died from their injuries. Wayne later turned himself into law enforcement and was charged with first-degree murder.

Around 8:15pm, a woman appeared on the University of Utah campus, reporting her husband had assaulted her while camping in the adjacent Red Butte Canyon. While she was being treated for an injury, her husband then shot a 23-year-old student in a car-jacking. The student died from his injuries. At least eight agencies, including the FBI, sent hundreds of officers to search the campus for the shooter, though he is believed to have escaped into the foothills above Red Butte Canyon.

A 15-year-old girl was sitting in the backseat of a car in the parking lot at Pattengill Academy when she was unintentionally shot by a man, who was also in the vehicle. The girl sustained non-life threatening injuries. Police locked down the school for an hour, moving all the students into the gymnasium. The man, 21, was subsequently charged with carrying a concealed weapon and careless discharge of a weapon.

Two shuttle bus drivers, contracted by Texas Christian University, got into an argument on campus. When the argument escalated, one of the drivers attempted to shoot the other, missed, and then knocked over the man over using his vehicle. Police put the university on temporary lockdown. The shooter was arrested and charged with aggravated assault.

A student brought a low-caliber handgun to school in a book bag. It was discharged unintentionally in a classroom, inflicting non-life threatening injuries on two students. Police announced that they were investigating the incident. Three students will face charges: one for possession of a weapon and possessing a weapon on campus; the other two for reckless conduct with a weapon.

Arriving late to class, an eight-year-old student began going through his book bag at the rear of the room when a handgun in the bag unintentionally discharged. No injuries were reported. The student was arrested and police announced he will face four charges, including carrying a weapon in a school safety zone. The handgun -- a Smith & Wesson nine-millimeter -- was previously reported stolen after a burglary in October.

A student was sitting in his car, showing his gun to another student when the gun fired, hitting him in the leg. He sustained non-life threatening injuries. Texarkana College allows students to conceal carry; the college president announced that the shooting would not change this policy.

A man pulled out a gun and opened fire on another man and his friends. A female, who was changing her shoes, was hit in the foot. The other man, who was originally shot at, was grazed by a bullet on his back. Police later found additional bullet holes in the driver and passenger side doors of the female's car. Nobody was able to identify the shooter, though campus police are still investigating.

Intent: Self-harm - no intent to hurt others
Narrative: A 17-year-old student, fatally shot himself in the courtyard near the bus loop at Lake Minneola High School.

As part of a shooting rampage which resulted in multiple casualties, the shooter attempted to enter Rancho Tehama Elementary School. However, before he arrived staff heard gunshots and initiated a lockdown. When the shooter found he could not enter, he shot dozens of rounds at the buildings instead. A six-year-old student sustained non-life threatening injuries in the chest and foot. Nobody else was hurt at the school.

Officers were called to North Side High School after shots were fired in a parking lot following the North Side-Liberty Tech High School basketball game. The school was placed in a brief lockdown, but there were no injuries and no arrests.

Two or three people walked up to a car in the parking lot of Manual High School and opened fire on the passengers inside. An adult woman was hit in the leg, a juvenile male was hit in the arm, and a second juvenile male sustained multiple gunshot wounds. All three were taken to the hospital for treatment. Police are investigating the incident to identify suspects. A motive has not yet been determined.

A man, 21, opened fire on Booksin Elementary School at 4 am with a shotgun, damaging a wall and a security camera near the school's library. He was later arrested and booked for possessing a firearm in a school zone, shooting a firearm in a school zone, discharging a firearm at an uninhabited building, and vandalism.

A male referee was attending a basketball officials meeting inside the school's cafeteria when a handgun, concealed inside his coat pocket, unintentionally fired, striking the floor. The referee was a valid CCW permit holder, but police charged him with illegal possession of a firearm in a school safety zone.

Intent: Self-harm - no intent to hurt others
Narrative: During an event involving students and more than 200 parents, a male student shot and killed himself inside a school bathroom. The school was put into temporary lockdown as police responded to what was initially described as a "medical emergency."

A man, 21, disguised himself as a student to gain entry to Aztec High School. He was discovered hiding in a second-floor bathroom, when he opened fire on a student, killing him. He then shot another student in the hallway, before fatally shooting himself. Police found a thumb drive on his body that contained files detailing his plans to attack the school.
A single shot was fired at High Point Central High School. No one was injured, and police are looking for the suspect.

A pizza delivery man, 58, was making a delivery on the school campus when three people attacked him. The individuals ordered the pizza with the intent of robbing the delivery man During the robbery, One of the students opened fire, hitting the delivery man in the face. He later died from his injuries. Police filed homicide charges against the three assailants.

Two men, 20 and 21, were making a delivery on the school grounds, when someone unintentionally fired a gun in their car. A single bullet struck one man's hand and then the other man's abdomen. Both of the men were taken for treatment at a nearby hospital.

A cook in the campus cafeteria, 49, was taking a shift break in her parked car, waiting for her ex-husband to arrive. Her ex-husband, 52, approached the woman's car, had a brief conversation with her, then pulled out a semi-automatic handgun and shot her, before shooting himself. Both died in what police described as a domestic violence shooting. Two students and a custodian witnessed the shooting.

A student brought a loaded gun to class in a backpack. During class, it unintentionally discharged in the backpack; nobody was injured. Police are investigating to determine if charges should be filed or Child Protective Services involved.

A group of young women were fighting in the parking lot of Beecher High School following a boys' basketball game. The fight escalated, and shots were fired. A teenage male was hit and injured with what police believe was a stray bullet. They continue to investigate the incident.

A couple pulled into the parking lot of Lincoln Elementary School to continue an argument. As they fought, a man in a black jacket approached the car, interjected, and fired twice at the man, hitting him in the forearm. The shooter then fled. The man was taken to a hospital and treated for non-life threatening injuries.

Two men, 18 and 19, entered Pinewood Elementary school on New Year's Eve, and fired their guns more than 60 times, causing tens of thousands of dollars in damage to classrooms and the library. No one was injured. Police believe the shooters timed the vandalism to coincide with New Years fireworks so neighbors would not get suspicious.

Shots were fired by an unidentified shooter into the main administrative office of New Start High School. At least one bullet went through a window into a filing cabinet. The school went into immediate lockdown, though nobody was injured.

Intent: Self-harm - no intent to hurt others
Narrative: Using a gun from home, a 14-year-old seventh grader shot himself in the head inside the bathroom at Coronado Elementary School. The shooting was initially reported as an active shooter, bringing local authorities to campus after it was locked down. Police later announced that no charges are pending against the family member who owned the gun.

Gunshots, which most likely originated off-campus, hit a window of the visual arts building at California State University, San Bernardino. Classes were immediately canceled as the university went into lockdown, though a police search failed to turn up any shooter on campus.

A criminal justice club student picked up a loaded gun, belonging to an advisor, which the student thought was an unloaded training weapon. She then shot at a wall target, unintentionally firing a bullet, which went through the wall and broke a window. The advisor was a licensed peace officer permitted to carry a firearm on campus.

A vehicle thought to be occupied by two people drove into the parking lot at Wiley College. Gunshots were fired, one of which hit the window of a residence hall. None of the three people inside were injured. The driver left the scene before police could arrive.

A man, 32, was confronted by police on the school’s athletic fields after a suspected robbery of a credit union earlier in the day. During a 50-minute negotiation, he made threatening statements and declined to surrender his weapon, a BB gun authorities took for a handgun. The man was shot seven times — nine officers fired more than a dozen bullets — and died at a hospital from rifle wounds to his torso. Prosecutors later ruled that the use of deadly force was justified.

A student at Winston-Salem State University, 21, was attending a sorority party at Wake Forest University when he got into an argument with another person. The argument escalated, the other person fired shots, and the student was critically hit. The shooter then left the campus. The shooter was later arrested in August at a home in Charlotte. He has been charged with murder, possession of a stolen firearm, and carrying a concealed gun.

An unknown person in a pickup truck drove past The NET Charter High School and fired shots at students standing in the campus parking lot.  An unidentified boy, 14, was injured with an abrasion, though police said that it was not a gunshot wound. Police also discovered that another student had gunshot residue on his hands, while a third was carrying live ammunition and was later arrested. They are continuing to investigate the situation.

A 16-year-old male student opened fire in the cafeteria at Italy High School, hitting a 15-year-old girl in the neck and abdomen. After taking aim at a second student and missing, the boy was confronted by a school staff member. He was apprehended before he could leave the campus. The injured student was airlifted to an area hospital. Police announced that they are continuing to investigate.

A 15-year-old male student opened fire on other students at Marshall County High School, shooting continuously as people attempted to flee. One student, 15, was killed at the scene, while another student, also 15, died a short time later at a hospital. Preliminary reports suggest that 14 other students were also shot, some sustaining critical injuries. An additional four people sustained other injuries as they tried to escape. Police have not yet released the name of the shooter, who was apprehended, and are continuing to investigate.

A disagreement between two 16-year-old students escalated when one pulled out a handgun. School administrators noticed the weapon and tried to calm him; the boy then fled across campus. He was pursued by staff until he fired the gun four or five times into the air. Nobody was injured. The shooter was taken into custody and charged for multiple offenses, including possession of a weapon on school property.

Two individuals became involved in an altercation during a basketball game at Dearborn High School. School officials removed them from the building, but one of the individuals was then shot at from a moving vehicle in the parking lot. No injuries were reported.

A fight began in the school parking lot outside a basketball game, and the school went into lockdown after shots were fired. A 32-year-old male was transported by private vehicle to Nazareth Hospital with two gunshot wounds in his leg. He was transferred by helicopter to another hospital, but died from his injuries. Police announced that they are searching for an adult male suspect.

A 12-year-old female student unintentionally discharged a handgun in a school classroom. A 15-year-old boy was shot in the head and a 15-year-old girl was shot in the wrist. Police arrested the female shooter and charged her with negligent discharge of a firearm. The source of the gun and why she had it on school grounds remains under investigation.

A school liaison officer was sitting on a bench talking with some students when a third-grader pressed the trigger on the officer's holstered weapon, causing it to fire and strike the floor. The holster was equipped with a trigger guard designed to prevent such unintentional discharges, so the department is reviewing the circumstances surrounding the event.

A 17-year-old male student got into an argument in the school parking lot and was shot twice in the chest. He walked into the school building, seeking help, and was transported to the hospital in a critical condition. Police said a preliminary investigation suggested robbery was the motive. They charged two people, 17 and 18, with attempted murder. They claim there was a 3rd unidentified person in the vehicle that pulled the trigger.
A 17 year-old male student fired a gun, hitting the floor of a classroom. No injuries were reported, and police took the student in custody for questioning.

Armed with an AR-15 assault rifle, a man, 19, returned to the school that had expelled him the year before for disciplinary reasons. He opened fire, killing at least 17 children and adults. At least an additional 17 were also injured during the attack. The shooter blended himself into the student crowd to escape; he was taken into custody an hour later. Authorities charged him with 17 counts of first-degree murder and 17 counts of attempted first-degree murder.

A sound thought to be a gunshot put North Broward Preparatory School on lockdown. During the investigation of what turned out to be a false alarm, a Broward Sheriff’s Office deputy unintentionally discharged his firearm, injuring his leg. The deputy was treated at the scene.

A boy, 13, wrote an eight-step plan for a school shooting that indicated he had an admiration for the Columbine shooters. He concealed a semiautomatic rifle beneath his clothes and caught the bus to school. He entered a bathroom, removed the rifle, and stepped out into a hallway brandishing it. He then re-entered the bathroom, where a student saw the firearm and left to notify staff. The boy shot himself fatally with the rifle. No other people were injured. Police found "distractionary devices" in his backpack and about 80 rounds of ammunition.

A fight broke out in the early hours of the morning near a university assembly hall where sporting events are routinely held. Shots were fired, and two student athletes sustained non-life threatening injuries. Authorities later arrested two other people, neither of them students, and announced they would both be charged with attempted murder.

Gunshots were fired near University Commons, and a 20-year-old former student was hit multiple times. The campus was placed on lockdown for approximately two hours while police investigated the incident. They arrested a suspect and charged him with carrying a weapon in school safety zones, and possession of a firearm during commission or attempt to commit certain felonies. The victim was taken to a hospital but later died as a result of his injuries.

At least two male students were in a school bathroom when a gun fired, sending a single bullet through the floor into a room below. A 14-year-old girl, who was in the room the bullet entered, collected the round and handed it to a teacher as the school was evacuated. Two students were subsequently arrested, one of them a 19 year-old who was booked for unlawfully possessing a firearm, reckless endangerment, and possessing a weapon on school property.

An unidentified person was shot and sustained non-life threatening injuries in the Charles Lackey Recreation Center, reportedly after a disagreement between a small group escalated into violence. Police are investigating the incident and seeking a suspect.

A student was studying in his dorm room at 1 am when he heard a loud noise in the room next door and realized he'd been shot. Police responded to the scene but failed to find a suspect. The injured student was taken to a local hospital with non-life threatening injuries.

A social studies teacher barricaded himself inside a classroom and fired a gun through an exterior window. The school went into immediate lockdown, though nobody was shot. After a 30-45 minute standoff, authorities arrested the teacher, who then refused to explain his actions. He was charged with six offenses, including, among others, aggravated assault, carrying a weapon on school grounds, and terroristic threats.

A man, 19, shot and killed his mother and father in a residence hall, causing more than 100 police officers to respond and placing the university on lockdown. After an extensive search, the shooter was taken into custody and charged with two counts of murder and one count of possession of a weapon to commit murder. A gun recovered at the scene was registered to the shooter's father, who worked in law enforcement.

After getting into a disagreement with another person, a man, 19, fired a gun towards a university residence hall, hitting a window. Police took him into custody within minutes and later announced that they were charging him with aggravated assault with a deadly weapon, deadly conduct, theft of a firearm, and unlawful carry of a weapon in prohibited places.

Intent: Self-harm - no intent to hurt others
Narrative: A teen, 17, had breakfast with his friends in the school cafeteria and then went into a bathroom and shot himself with a .22-caliber handgun. Police announced that they are investigating the incident.

A teen, 17, unintentionally discharged a firearm inside Huffman High School, fatally hitting a student, 17, and injuring himself. After reviewing video footage of the incident, police charged the shooter with manslaughter and illegally possessing a pistol for bringing a gun on school grounds and “recklessly causing the death” of the victim.

A 16 year-old male student unintentionally shot himself with a gun he had smuggled into a classroom, sustaining an injury to his left thumb. Police announced they were charging him with wanton endangerment and possession of a weapon on school property. After the shooting, the school superintendent announced that stationary metal detectors would be installed and all students would be required to enter through them.

While teaching public safety in an Administration of Justice class, a teacher and reserve police officer unintentionally discharged his gun into the ceiling. Three students were injured by bullet fragments or debris, none seriously. The teacher was placed on administrative leave and the Seaside PD opened an investigation.

A school resource officer unintentionally fired his weapon inside his office at George Washington Middle School. He checked the area for any injuries—there were none—and notified his superiors. Classes continued as normal.

A juvenile probation officer and the student resource officer were investigating a student after being given a photograph of him holding a gun. While the student involved was being questioned, he ran into the parking lot, pursued by the SRO. The student then attempted to hit the SRO with his car; the SRO responded by shooting at the car. The student was later apprehending after crashing his vehicle. A handgun believed to be thrown from the student's car was also recovered.

A teen, 17, opened fire with a handgun in an academic building at Great Mills High School, critically injuring a 16-year-old girl and hitting a 14-year-old boy before being confronted by the school's resource officer. The officer engaged the shooter in gunfire, hitting him in the hand at the same moment the shooter fatally shot himself in the head. The school went into immediate lockdown. The injured girl was later pronounced brain dead and taken off life support.

A man, 20, fired shots at Eupora High School after riding a dirt-bike through the courtyard. The man, who was former student at the school, was arrested and charged for possessing an unregistered weapon, discharging and possessing a firearm in a school zone, and possessing a firearm as a current drug user.

Gunfire erupted during a track meet at Raytown South Middle School. The shots were fired in the school parking lot, and one man sustained non life-threatening injuries from being hit in the stomach. The shooter, who was not identified, fled in a small black compact car. Police are continuing to investigate the incident.

Shots likely fired off-campus hit a school building, with bullets entering two classrooms where students were present. The school went into lockdown, though no injuries were reported. Police announced that they were investigating the incident to determine if the school was an intended target.

A man, 19, blended in with students and entered the school with a shotgun concealed in a guitar case. He then fired at a classroom door, injuring a 17-year old boy in the ankle. The school resource officer arrived on the scene within minutes; The shooter was taken into custody without incident.

A female student got into an argument with a man, 19, in the school parking lot, which resulted in the man breaking a car window and injuring the student by broken glass. As the man drove away, he fired at least one shot into the air, sending the campus into lockdown. He was later arrested by the U.S. Marshals Southeast Regional Fugitive Task Force and charged with multiple offenses.

A 19-year-old custodian at Enemy Swim Day School was conducting a perimeter check when he was shot and injured. He was treated for his injuries, and police arrested a suspect in connection to the incident. Police do not believe there was any danger to other students or staff members.
A student brought a gun to school and unintentionally discharged it inside a bathroom. The school went into lockdown, but no injuries were reported.

An off-duty police officer, watching his son compete at a high school wrestling meet, unintentionally discharged a handgun. A bullet hit the gymnasium floor but did not strike anyone. The meet was paused for fifty minutes before resuming.

A 14-year-old former student shot and wounded a 15-year-old boy at Highland High School with an SKS rifle, which he then discarded in a field after fleeing the scene. He was arrested by an off-duty police officer in a nearby supermarket. Immediately following the shooting, the school went into temporary lockdown.

A former student fired several shots near the school gym where students were practicing for a graduation ceremony. He was confronted by a school resource officer and fled the school, pursued by the officer on foot, according to a preliminary police investigation. They exchanged gunfire, with the former student shooting first; the officer was unhurt but the shooter sustained non-life threatening injuries. He was later charged with aggravated discharge of a firearm. The school was placed on temporary lockdown.
After a graduation ceremony, an argument occurred in the parking lot of Mount Zion High School. Shots were fired, killing a woman in her 40s and wounding a 21-year-old.

Armed with a shotgun and revolver reportedly owned legally by his father, a 17-year-old student opened fire on classmates and staff at Santa Fe High School, killing ten, and injuring at least 13 others. He eventually surrendered and was taken into custody by police, who also found two homemade explosive devices left at the school by the student.

A child picked up a handgun that had been left unsecured on the backseat of a car in the parking lot at Beverbrook Elementary School. The gun was then fired unintentionally, hitting and injuring a woman, 24. The gun belonged to the woman's friend, who was licensed to possess it. No students were injured.

A male student asked to be excused from class, then returned armed with two handguns. He opened fire, hitting a 13 year-old girl in the chest and the class's teacher, when the teacher intervened. The student was taken into custody; both the girl and the teacher were taken to hospital to be treated for their injuries.

Intent: Self-harm - no intent to hurt others
Narrative: A male student brought a gun to school and shot himself in an empty classroom. No other student was injured, and the school was placed on immediate lockdown until police could confirm that there was no further threat.
While inside Vero Beach High School, an officer unintentionally discharged his weapon into his own hand.
Following a road rage confrontation, a man was pursued over a fence onto the Compton College campus, where he was shot by the unknown assailant. Police are investigating the incident.
An altercation on the basketball courts at Valley Elementary School led to a shot fired. No injuries were reported, and a 17-year-old was arrested in connection to the incident.
A man, 30, was shot multiple times and killed on the running track at the temporary site of Grant High School. Police have not identified any suspects and are continuing to investigate.

A woman was walking at 5:30am on the school's running track when she was approached by a person and shot in the ankle. The shooter fled, but was later apprehended, and the woman was transported to a nearby hospital to be treated for non-life threatening injuries.

Two teenage boys were shot and injured by an unidentified male on the campus of Sentinel High School. Both boys were transported to a nearby hospital for surgery. At the time of the shooting, an open gym meet was taking place at the school; athletes were temporarily held inside the gym until they could be collected by their parents. Police are continuing to investigate.

While installing playground equipment at Sunrise Point Elementary School, a man, 32, shot and killed a man, 48, and critically injured another man, 54, both of whom were his coworkers. School was out of session at the time, and no students were present. The shooter was charged with first-degree murder and attempted first-degree murder.

A group of juveniles was fighting on the grounds of Milkovich Middle School. Shots were fired, leading to the injury and subsequent death of a 20-year-old man. Police arrested two people in connection with the incident.

A man was arguing with another man in a parking lot behind the school's football field and pulled out a handgun. He fired a shot into the ground, trying to scare the other man. Nobody was injured. The shooter was charged with wanton endangerment by police.

An unidentified individual shot a man, 19, in the school parking lot on a Friday night. Police responded to reports of gunfire and found the man in a car with a gunshot to his upper body. He was transported to a hospital and pronounced dead.

A football coach was shot and killed in a car in the school parking lot by an unknown assailant, who immediately fled the scene. Approximately 200 people fled for cover at the sound of gunshots. Police are continuing to investigate.

After breaking up an altercation between two students, a 42-year-old football coach was shot and injured in the leg by one of the students' fathers, who was angry over the way the coach had intervened. The coach was transported to Vanderbilt Hospital for treatment. The shooter fled the scene. Police are continuing to investigate.

During a practice football game, gunfire erupted just outside the school stadium. Two men were injured in the shooting and were taken to a hospital for treatment. The stadium was immediately evacuated. Police are continuing to investigate.

A teen, 16, opened fire after a Raines High School football game, killing a man, 19, and injuring two teenagers. The shooter has been charged with one count of second-degree murder and two counts of attempted murder.

Intent: Self-harm - no intent to hurt others
Narrative: On the second day of classes, a professor of sociology shot himself in the arm in a campus bathroom. While waiting for responders to arrive, the professor said that he shot himself in protest of President Donald Trump. He has been charged with discharging a gun within a prohibited structure, carrying a concealed weapon without a permit and possessing a dangerous weapon on school property.

A custodian at Towne Point Elementary School, 53, was involved in a dispute with a man, 39, in the school parking lot. The custodian shot the man four times before driving away from the scene, leaving him dead. The shooter was later arrested and charged with first-degree murder, possession of a firearm during the commission of a felony, and possession of a weapon in a safe school zone.

A man, 34, followed a vehicle carrying his ex-girlfriend and her child into the parking lot of Villa Heights Elementary School and began firing shots at the vehicle. Neither the ex-girlfriend nor her child was injured, and the school was placed on lockdown in response.

A 14-year-old freshman student brought a gun to class and unintentionally discharged it while playing with it. He fled campus but was turned in by his mother. The shooter was charged with 8 felony charges, including possession of a firearm on campus, possession of live ammunition, and negligent discharge, and three other students were arrested as possible accessories after the fact.

A man recklessly drove a stolen car onto an unattended baseball field on campus. He accelerated towards a responding officer who fired a shot at the car, and was eventually restrained without injury. The school was hosting a youth football tournament, located directly across from the field, where people were told to shelter in place during the incident.

A student injured their hand when they tried to pass a pistol to another student during gym class and it unintentionally discharged. They had brought the gun from home and intended to show it off. The student was taken into custody after the incident.

Intent: Self-harm - no intent to hurt others
Narrative: A man was found near the bleachers with what appeared to be a self-inflicted gunshot wound. Police believe he entered school grounds the night before and shot himself before classes began that morning.

Intent: Self-harm - no intent to hurt others
Narrative: A 16-year-old student was found with a self-inflicted gunshot wound in the fine arts building of the school. He was flown to a hospital for treatment but died of his injuries. The school was put on lockdown in response to the incident.

A man, 25, exited a vehicle in the school parking lot and began shooting at a vehicle that was leaving the school after the driver had just dropped off a child. No one was injured. The shooter was charged with possession of a firearm by a convicted felon, assault with a deadly weapon with intent to kill, possession of a weapon on school grounds and discharging a weapon on school grounds.

Two students each brought a semi-automatic weapon to school and were playing with the weapons in a bathroom when one discharged. No injuries were reported. The school was placed on lockdown in response.

A man shot another man in the chest during an argument outside of a high school football game. The men started arguing in the stadium and then went to a parking lot on school grounds, where the incident occurred. The man who was shot was taken to the hospital in critical condition.
A building at Chicot Elementary School was struck six times by gunfire. No one was injured, and police believe that the shooter was not targeting the school.

A man, 26, dropped a student off at school and walked back to his car when he got into an altercation with another man. The man shot the other man one time in the chest and fled the scene but was arrested nearby shortly after. He has been charged with first-degree assault and fourth-degree misconduct involving a weapon.

A woman was picking up her child in the school cafeteria when she dropped a bag that contained a gun in it and it discharged. No one was injured, and the school went into lockdown in response to the incident. The woman had left the school but was arrested a few blocks away.
A shooting occurred in the parking lot of Lake Taylor High School after a football game. Gunshots struck a car, and one person was injured by broken class from the car window.
A basketball coach was shot during a fight at a pick-up basketball game on the Varina High School campus. He was taken to a hospital for treatment of non-life-threatening injuries.

Several people were involved in an argument at the top of North High Street on the West Virginia University campus when one of them produced a handgun and fired into the air several times before leaving the scene. No one was injured.
A bullet shattered a window on the southside entrance to Battle Creek Academy. No one was injured, and the school was placed on lockdown in response to the incident.

Two vehicles arrived at the high school parking lot. A man threatened another man with a gun. As the man who had been threatened drove off, the other man shot at his car, fatally wounding him. The victim's relative, who was also in the vehicle, suffered a graze wound.

Shots were fired near Lexington and Greene streets on the University of Maryland's Baltimore campus. No one was injured. University police apprehended two suspects, one of whom told police that two other men tried to assault him and he fired shots in self-defense.

A man, 18, became upset with his mother's boyfriend and fired a gun at him. The bullet struck a window at nearby Dunbar Elementary School as students were arriving for class that morning. No one was injured. The shooter has been charged with attempted first-degree assault, unlawful discharge, carrying a pistol without a permit, reckless endangerment and risk of injury to a child.

A student at the University of Utah was found shot and killed in a parking lot outside of a residence hall. The suspected gunman, 37, had a prior relationship with the victim and the two had been in dispute. The shooter was found dead of a self-inflicted gunshot wound in a church outside of campus.
Shots were fired at a 15-year-old student outside Cody High School. The student was not injured. Police arrested three people in connection to the incident.

Two students were fighting in a crowded hallway when one of them shot the other. The victim was transported to a hospital but died of his injuries. The shooter was taken into custody, and the school was placed on lockdown in response.

Two men, both in their twenties, were shot in the parking lot of Crums Lane Elementary School. One of the men, 21, was pronounced dead at the scene. The other was transported to a hospital for treatment of non-life-threatening injuries.

Two men entered a dormitory room on the campus of Urbana University, intending to rob a group during a drug deal. One man in the room used a gun to hit two other men on the head, causing one of them to drop his gun which then discharged. No one was shot. Two men were charged with aggravated robbery, and three men were charged with marijuana trafficking. One was additionally charged with carrying a concealed weapon.
A 12-year-old student unintentionally discharged a gun in the bathroom. The gun had been brought to school in a backpack. Two students have been charged in connection with the incident.

A man suffering from a gunshot wound was found on the campus of Cleveland Elementary School after police responded to reports of shots fired in the area of the school. Two men were arrested in connection with the incident.
Two men were shot on Voorhees College campus after a homecoming event. One of the men, 26, died, and the other man was injured. Neither of the victims were students at the school.

A 17-year-old unintentionally discharged a weapon inside the University of Akron Exchange Street Residence Hall, striking a 19-year-old in the abdomen. The 19-year-old was transported to a hospital for treatment. Neither were students at the university, and police have detained the 17-year-old for unlawful discharge of a firearm.

Intent: Self-harm - no intent to hurt others
Narrative: A school resource officer at Eastern Technical High School fatally shot himself in his office at the school. He was transported to a hospital and pronounced dead. The school was placed on lockdown in response. No students or other staff were injured.

School name: University of North Texas at Dallas
Narrative: A man, 42, was engaged in an argument with a 41-year-old man, who was a student at the university, over child custody on the campus's parking lot. The 42-year-old man pulled out a gun and shot the 41-year-old man, then got into the victim's vehicle and fled the scene. He crashed a short distance away after running into a car being driven by the mother of the child in dispute. Neither the mother or the child were injured in the crash. The shooter has been charged with aggravated robbery and two counts of aggravated assault, and the victim was taken to a hospital for treatment of non-life-threatening injuries.

A man, 29, brought a gun to Simonsdale Elementary school just before dismissal and unintentionally discharged it, striking and injuring a woman in the lower body after the bullet ricocheted. The school was placed on lockdown in response to the incident. The man has been charged with possession of a firearm on school property, possession of a firearm by a felon, and reckless handling of a firearm.

Two groups had gathered to play a Thanksgiving football pickup game at Mount Rainier High School, which was closed for the holiday. The two groups then got into a dispute, and one person flashed a gun before leaving. Two others then returned and fatally shot a  21-year-old man before fleeing the scene.

School name: Columbus Africentric Early College High School
Narrative: A man, 20, and another man were shot and injured after multiple fights broke out at the parking lot of Africentric Early College. Both victims self-transported to nearby hospitals and were treated for injuries.
A bullet pierced a third floor window of Strawberry Mansion High School. The school was placed on lockdown in response. No one was hurt, and most students had already been dismissed from the school.
A fist fight at the center of campus led to shots being fired. The school was placed on lockdown in response. No one was hit or hurt, and the people involved in the fight fled the scene.

Intent: Self-harm - no intent to hurt others
Narrative: A 17-year-old male student was found dead of a gunshot wound on the baseball fields at Jefferson High School. Police said they were investigating the death as a suicide.

Two people were injured by gunfire in the parking lot of Cawood Elementary School. A man, 20, was struck in the eye and transported to a hospital in serious condition, and a 15-year-old girl was shot in the hip area but did not seek immediate medical attention.

Police received a tip that there was someone en route to commit a violent act at Dennis Intermediate School. When they responded, they confronted a teenager outside the school. The teenager and the responding officers exchanged gunfire until the teen went inside the school and fatally shot himself. No students or officers were injured, and the school was evacuated.
A student at Winnetonka High School fired a gun into the air in the parking lot of the school. No one was injured, and the school went into lockdown in response.
A police officer assigned to Snyder High School was cleaning his gun when it fired. No one was harmed, and the officer was removed from his assignment at the school.

Two men working in the motor pool at the Biscayne Bay Campus were involved in an altercation when one of them pulled out a gun and fired into the air. Both men were detained, and no one was shot or injured.

Intent: Self-harm - no intent to hurt others
Narrative: A former student at the Mississippi University for Women shot and wounded himself near the campus's main auditorium. Classes were not in session at the time of the incident, and the victim was taken to a hospital for treatment.

A man, 17, was fatally shot in the parking lot of Central Elementary School. Responders found him after a family member contacted them and claimed he was in trouble. Police investigating the incident believe that the shooter had a connection to Othman.

A 30-year-old man showed up at Cascade Middle School amid a custody dispute. As he was being escorted away from the school, the man began to struggle and pulled out a gun, and a school resource officer fatally shot him. The school was locked down in response.
Gunfire struck the front entrance of North High School. No one was injured.

Five students from Blue Valley High school were in the parking lot of Lakewood Middle School when someone fired buckshot that struck a 16-year-old boy in the head during a suspected robbery. A 15-year-old also sustained non-gunshot-related injuries in the incident after someone hit him with a pistol. Both are expected to recover from their injuries.
A 15-year-old shot and wounded a 17-year-old and a 20-year-old after a basketball game at the Davidson High School gym. Both were taken to a hospital and treated for non-life-threatening injuries.
A woman was killed by a self-inflicted gunshot while at a shooting range on the Michigan State University campus.

A 35-year-old man was running on the track of Miller Grove High School when he saw someone trying to break into his vehicle, which was parked on school property. He confronted the person who then shot and injured him.
Shots were fired at a campus basketball court at Prairie View A&M University. No injuries were reported.

A 16-year-old student of Atascocita High School was shot in the foot and suffered a graze wound on his hip or torso. A teen, 17, was arrested and charged with aggravated assault in connection with the incident.

A man, 25, went to Frederick Douglass High School to confront a staffer, 56, after he disciplined a relative of the teen who was a student at the school. The teen opened fire on the staffer, shooting him twice in the right torso and injuring him. The shooter faces more than a dozen charges, including attempted murder, assault, and several gun violations.

Following an argument during a basketball game at the Central Academy of Excellence, a 15-year-old girl was shot while leaving the building by a 21-year-old woman waiting for her in a van outside. The victim was transported to hospital where she was pronounced dead. The 21-year-old woman and an 18-year-old woman, who was driving the car, have been charged in the murder.

A 16-year-old student intent on killing his ex-girlfriend fired a shot towards a group of people inside V. Sue Cleveland High School before classes began that morning. No injuries were reported, and the student was taken into custody.
A 37-year-old man went to Uta Halee Academy intending to target a staff member, and attempted to gain access to an administrative building. When he failed, he shot and killed himself.

A man, 31, and another man, 46, met in a parking lot on the campus of Eaglecrest High School to settle an ongoing dispute over a parking space in their neighborhood. During the argument, the 31-year-old man shot the other man and left the campus. The 41-year-old man later died of his injuries. The shooter has been charged with first-degree murder.
A 22-year-old was unintentionally shot in the foot in a New Jersey City University residence hall.
A 17-year-old student was shot and wounded in the gym area of Lee High School. The school was put on lockdown in response. Police detained a 17-year-old suspect in connection with the incident.

Intent: Self-harm - no intent to hurt others
Narrative: A Claremont McKenna University student died of a self-inflicted gunshot wound in his dorm room.

A 17-year-old student of Cheyenne South High School fired a gun at the window of an unoccupied vehicle in the school's parking lot. The student was arrested. No one was injured, and the school was placed on lockdown in response.

Gunfire broke out near Highlands Elementary School while school staff were monitoring students on the playground. At least one bullet struck the school building. No students or staff were hurt. Police in the area responded to the incident and confronted the alleged shooter, 26, and arrested him after he pointed a gun at them.

A woman, 30, was parked near Steelton Highspire Elementary School when she unintentionally discharged a gun, injuring herself and damaging a vehicle in the high school's adjacent parking lot. She has been charged with reckless endangerment, possessing a weapon on school property, criminal mischief, and filing false police reports to law enforcement.

A student was shot and injured in a Grambling State University dormitory. A man, 20, was arrested and charged with "carrying a firearm on school property, carrying it in a firearm-free zone, possessing marijuana and possessing a firearm after a felony conviction."

Intent: Self-harm - no intent to hurt others
Narrative: A 17-year-old student at Lake Mary High School fatally shot herself in the school's auditorium. The school was placed on lockdown and there was no threat to the campus.
Shots were fired in a parking lot at Christian Brothers University. Police investigating the incident believed the individuals involved knew each other and fled the scene after the incident.

A man unintentionally discharged a firearm inside a bathroom at Chemeketa Community College. No one was injured. The man has been charged with second-degree criminal mischief, first-degree burglary, carrying a concealed firearm and unlawful use of a firearm.

Police were called to the University of Wisconsin - Milwaukee for a report of a man sleeping inside a building on the campus. When police confronted the man, a physical altercation ensued and police discovered he had a weapon. The man was shot during the altercation. No students or staff were hurt.

A man, 74, was working as a substitute teacher at Blountsville Elementary School when a gun in his pocket discharged. A first-grade student was struck by a fragment and injured. The man has been charged with reckless endangerment, third-degree aggravated assault and possession of a firearm on school grounds.
A shot was fired from a car on Vanderbilt University's campus after a party was broken up because of several fights. No one was injured.
A man was shot on the campus of Virginia Commonwealth University. He was transported to a hospital with non-life-threatening injuries.
A gunshot damaged a parked car in a West Carolina University parking lot. No one was injured.
Four people entered a campus apartment and demanded money from a student and a guest inside, who were shot and injured when a fight ensued. The suspects fled the scene.

A 14-year-old student brought a concealed handgun to Prescott High School and shot and injured another 14-year-old student. Officials believe the shooting was premediated. The school went into lockdown in response.

School name: New Joseph Bonnheim Community Charter School
Narrative: Two gunshots struck a New Joseph Bonnheim Community Charter School building after a shooting in the area. No injuries were reported.
Gunfire struck Saint Clair Evans Academy during a shooting in the area, with one shot breaking the window of a third grade classroom. No students or staff were hurt.
An employee of St. Josaphat Parish School brought a gun to school and discharged it, grazing a 10-year-old student. The employee was arrested after the incident was reported to police.
Bullet holes were found in a classroom wall at Hood Elementary School. Police believe the incident occurred over the weekend and that the school was not targeted.

School name: Ross Shaw Sterling Aviation High School
Narrative: A 15-year-old student was playing basketball at Sterling Aviation High School when he was grazed in the arm by a stray bullet. Police believe the bullet was fired during a shooting at a nearby apartment complex.
A University of Montana student fired a gun out of a residence hall window. No injuries were reported.

Intent: Self-harm - no intent to hurt others
Narrative: A 7th-grade student shot himself in the restroom of George Washington Middle School. He was taken to Loyola University Medical Center where he died of his injuries. The school was placed on lockdown, and there was no danger to other students or staff.

A confrontation outside Flint Development Center, which houses Flex High School led to a shot being fired on the school's grounds. Police said the incident involved staff and students from the school, but no one was injured, and the school was placed on lockdown in response. Police arrested four suspects in connection with the incident.
An unknown suspect fired nine rifle shots into Springfield Elementary School, striking three windows and a side door. No injuries were reported.

School name: Dr. John D. Horn High School
Narrative: A school resource officer was inspecting his firearm in his office when it went off, firing a round of ammunition that was left inside the chamber. No injuries were reported.

Three juveniles were on the playground of Dove School of Discovery shooting a handgun that police suspect was stolen. Officers arrested two of the suspects for possession of a firearm on school property and reckless discharge of a firearm. The school was not open at the time, and no injuries were reported.

Intent: Self-harm - no intent to hurt others
Narrative: A 14-year-old student at Concord High School died of a self-inflicted gunshot wound in the school's cafeteria bathroom. The school was placed on lockdown in response.
A Bowling Green State University student unintentionally shot and wounded himself while in a campus parking lot.
A student brought a gun to Hylton High School and it discharged inside of a classroom. Police believe the incident was unintentional. No injuries were reported.

School name: University of North Carolina at Charlotte
Narrative: A man, 22, began shooting inside a campus building, killing two people and injuring four. Police apprehended the shooter and charged him with two counts of murder, four counts of attempted murder, four counts of assault with a deadly weapon with intent to kill, discharging a firearm on educational property, and possession of a firearm on educational property.
A school resource officer at Weightman Middle School was leaning against a cafeteria wall when his weapon discharged, firing a round into the wall behind him. No one injuries were reported.
A person was arrested for firing shots on the campus of Blinn College. No injuries were reported.
A man was in a University of Oregon-owned parking lot when he was fatally shot in the chest.

A student at Savannah State University was shot and injured outside an on-campus student housing complex. The school was placed on lockdown after the incident. Police arrested a suspect who is not a student at the school.
Two students ages 18 and 16 entered STEM School Highlands Ranch and began firing inside classrooms, killing an 18-year-old student and injuring eight others. Police took boys into custody.
A man on Jefferson State Community College brandished a machete at a campus police officer, who then fired at him. The man was transported to a nearby hospital for treatment.
A disagreement led to shots being fired in a parking lot on the campus of Kansas State University. No one was injured.
A person was exercising their dog on the campus of Grant High School when an unknown suspect shot and injured the dog.

A student, 16, was shot and injured after being approached by a group in the parking lot of Terry Parker High School's football stadium during a game. The student, who attended Raines High School, was taken to the hospital in critical condition, but later upgraded to stable. The police have arrested a man, 19, in connection with the shooting.
While searching the building of Lafayette Elementary School after an alarm activation, a Board of Education security officer unintentionally discharged their firearm. No one was injured.

Gunfire damaged the front window of Hendley Elementary School. DC police responded to the area for reports of shots fired but did not uncover the damage to the building during their initial search. The damage was discovered by staff the following morning.

A Georgia State University security guard was sitting inside the school's science center when a pistol kept in his backpack discharged, injuring him in the right thigh. The gun was not issued by university police.
A man was playing on the basketball court of Genevieve Melody STEM Elementary School when he was shot in the leg.

A bullet broke a window in the lobby of Hendley Elementary School. No injuries were reported. The school had scheduled a movie night co-sponsored with the DC police department at the time of the incident, and officers, teachers, and students were present.

School name: Dr Martin Luther King Jr School Complex
Narrative: A juvenile dropped a gun inside the Martin Luther King Jr. School Complex during a recreational basketball game, causing it to discharge. An officer who was already at the school responded to the incident.

A 15-year-old boy was shot in the chest during a fight that occurred outside a basketball game at Carman-Ainsworth High School. Police detained ten minors for questioning and recovered multiple weapons.

School name: School of Science and Applied Learning
Narrative: A 13-year-old boy was with other teens in the schoolyard of the School of Science and Applied Learning when he was shot in the chest. He was discovered one block away and was transported to a hospital for treatment. The shooter fled the scene before police arrived.

A 16-year-old boy was shot and seriously injured during a fight involving a large group of people on the playground of Williwaw Elementary School. A man, 22, was charged with first-degree assault and reckless endangerment in connection with the shooting.
A man, 34, was riding his bike through the parking lot of Bulkeley High School when he was shot. He died shortly after being transported to a hospital. The school was not in session at the time.
A juvenile fired a shot at Deer Creek Middle school. No one was injured, and three juveniles were arrested.

A man, 38, a father of a student at Wynton M. Blount Elementary School, got into an argument with another father in the parking lot of the school. He pulled out a gun and fired it. It struck the other's car. No one was injured, and Johnson was arrested on suspicion of discharging a firearm into an occupied vehicle.

A parent unintentionally discharged a firearm and injured himself in the parking lot of Saint Patrick School. The man, a corrections officer, fired his licensed service weapon. The school was holding a back-to-school night for elementary school parents at the time of the incident.

Four students, from Spellman University and Clark Atlanta University, were shot and injured on the steps a library on the campus of Clark Atlanta University. About 200 people were attending a block party celebrating the end of new student orientation when the shots were fired.

A 12-year-old boy was shot and injured at Peek's Chapel Elementary School. Authorities arrested and charged a 15-year-old boy with aggravated assault and aggravated battery in connection with the incident.
A 14-year-old boy was shot twice in the head while in the schoolyard of William C. Longstreth Elementary School. He was taken to a hospital where he died of his injuries.

A student was shot in the jaw while standing in line for lunch at Hollenbeck Middle School. The origin of the gunfire is unknown, though school officials believe it to be the result of an off-campus discharge.

A 36-year-old man fired at least three shots into the ground of a football field at Roosevelt High School after getting into a dispute over trees that had fallen onto his property. No one was injured. School was not in session at the time, but students were practicing on the field during the incident.
Shots were fired on the campus of Livingstone College. No one was injured.
A 16-year-old boy was shot and wounded by an unknown gunman after a football game at Central Catholic High School.

A 17-year-old and a 19-year-old fired shots into the air after a football game at Kinston High School. Both were charged with possession of a weapon on educational property, discharging a firearm on educational property, and going armed to the terror of the public, as well as drug-related charges. The 17-year-old was additionally charged with possession of a handgun by a minor.

Tulane University Police confronted a man wanted for arrest on suspicion of indecent exposure and trespassing. The man fled campus in his car, which a toddler was also in, and a Tulane officer fired at the car in an attempt to stop him. The man was later taken into custody when he arrived at a hospital with a gunshot wound.
A fight at a nearby convenience store led to gunfire in the parking lot of South Aiken High School. No injuries were reported, and two people were arrested in connection with the incident.
Shots were fired in the parking lot of Manhattan High School. No one was injured.
During a football game at Granger High School, shots were fired on another part of campus. No one was injured. Eight people were detained for questioning.
A woman was shot and injured when a dispute between parents at a pee-wee football game escalated. A 12-year-old child was additionally grazed by a bullet.

A man, 20, was shot multiple times on the campus of Fayetteville State University. Campus police charged a man, 24, with attempted first degree murder and assault with a deadly weapon with intent to kill inflicting serious injury.
Gunfire damaged a library and a parking garage at San Jose State University. No one was injured.
Two women were injured by gunfire on the campus of South Carolina State University. The shooting occurred after an off-campus altercation.
Gunfire was reported on the campus of Chowan University. No one was injured on campus.

Two people in separate cars were shooting at each other when a shot struck the window of a classroom at Aiton Elementary School. The students usually in the classroom were on a field trip during the incident, and no one was injured.
A group of people were fighting on the campus of Buffalo State College when one man fired a shot into the air. No one was injured.
A shot was fired into the air during a large fight at a softball game on the campus of South Atlanta High School.
A 21-year-old student at the University of Georgia unintentionally shot himself in the leg while in the school's Chemistry Building.
A student was shot and injured when a gun discharged on the campus of Westbury High School.
A 19-year-old was accidentally shot by a classmate in a residence hall on the Tennessee State University campus. He was transported to a hospital where he died of his injuries.
Two people, including a campus police officer, were shot and wounded on the campus of Grambling State University.
Shots were fired on the campus of Woodward High School during a football game. No injures were reported, and two people were detained.
A shotgun discharge damaged a window at South Ridge School. The school was locked down as officials investigated.
A student was shot and wounded on Georgia Southern University's Armstrong Campus.
A road rage incident led to one person firing shots on a road on the campus of University of Oregon. No one was injured.

A man, 22, was shot during a robbery on the campus of Austin Peay State University. He was transported to a hospital where he died of his injuries. Police arrested two people in connection with the incident, and an investigation revealed that the two suspects planned to meet the victim on campus for a drug deal.
A woman was shot and injured while with a group of people in the parking lot of Laurel Woods Elementary School.
A 30-year-old female student, was shot and killed by a 20-year-old male student in a Texas State Technical College on-campus rental home, following a two-hour argument about their relationship.

A University of Central Missouri student was shot and killed after a firearm was unintentionally discharged at an on-campus apartment. Police arrested a student on suspicion of involuntary manslaughter.
A man was shot and wounded in the leg outside a dorm on the campus of Langston University.

School name: Achievement Academy at Harbor City High School
Narrative: A 19-year-old male student was shot and wounded outside of a car on the campus of Achievement Academy.

A man, armed with a sword, was reported for violating a restraining order and causing a disturbance at his family's home. When police arrived at the home, he fled to nearby Esteban Torres High School. While on the campus of the school, the man advanced towards officers with the sword, and one of the officers fatally shot him.
Five students ages 14 and 15 were shot when a 16-year-old male student opened fire in the quad of Saugus High School. At least two were killed before the shooter fatally shot himself.

A 10-year-old boy was shot and killed and a 15-year-old boy and a 27-year-old man were wounded when gunfire erupted in the stands during a football game at Pleasantville High School. A 31-year-old man was charged with one count of murder, two counts of attempted murder, and weapons charges. Five other men, ages 26-28, including the 27-year-old victim, were also charged with weapons offenses.
A student unintentionally discharged a gun in a student apartment complex. The shot went through the ceiling and into another apartment in the building. No one was injured.
Two men were killed after a shooting on the campus of Florida Memorial University.
An 11-year-old boy and a 14-year-old boy were shot and killed while sitting in a van in the parking lot of Searles Elementary School.
A 20-year-old man was shot and killed on the campus of the Southern University of New Orleans.
An 18-year-old woman dropped her shotgun while at a Clemson University shooting range, causing it to discharge and strike her in the foot.

A man shot two people, killing one and injuring another, in the parking lot of Sarah J. Anderson Elementary School after school let out for the day. One of the victims had a restraining order against the shooter, and authorities believe the shooting was related to an ongoing domestic violence situation.

A man, 36, shot into the window of Riverbend Elementary School and entered the building. While inside, he continued to fire shots, damaging the building and attempting to activate the school's fire alarm. After 12 hours inside, he left the building and was later apprehended by police in Arkansas.
A man, 24, was shot on the campus of the Illinois Institute of Technology. He was transported to the University of Chicago Medical Center, where he died of his injuries.

A law enforcement officer shot and wounded a 17-year-old student at Waukesha South High School after the student pulled out a gun and refused to drop it. The student was taken into custody, and no one else was injured.
A school resource officer at Oshkosh West High School shot and wounded a 16-year-old student after the student stabbed the officer. Both were taken to a hospital with non-life-threatening injuries.
A school resource officer at Picacho Middle School unintentionally discharged his handgun while in his office. No one was shot.
Gunfire struck the side of a residence hall on the campus of Sam Houston State University. No one was injured.

School name: North Dakota State College of Science
Narrative: A firearm unintentionally discharged on the campus of North Dakota State College of Science, injuring a student.
A person with a concealed carry permit was showing a gun to a friend on the campus of Cleveland State Community College when it unintentionally discharged. No one was injured.

A 17-year-old student and a 16-year-old student were handling a handgun inside Maury High School when it discharged, striking the 17-year-old in the hand. Both students were charged in connection with the incident.

A man was targeted and shot multiple times and injured after dropping off a child at the Catholic Academy of New Haven. One shot went through a window into a preschool classroom where 11 children were present. No one else was injured.
A man, 32, was shot inside his apartment on the campus of Southwestern College. He died two days later in a Wichita hospital.
A woman was shot and killed by her ex-boyfriend, 50, in the parking lot of Lely High School. The shooter has been charged with second-degree murder in connection with the killing.
After a verbal altercation, a man fired shots on the campus of the University of Virginia. He was charged with attempted malicious wounding in connection with the incident.

Four people were shot at a birthday party at West St. John Elementary School. A man, 34, has been arrested on two counts of aggravated second-degree battery and illegal use of weapons in connection with the shooting. Authorities are searching for two additional shooters.
The Academy 1 Middle School building was hit by gunfire after shots were fired in the area. No one was injured.

School name: North Carolina State University at Raleigh
